headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to AutoNation's fourth quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time.Now I will turn the call over to Andrew Wamser, Treasurer and
componenttext:
Welcome to AutoNation's fourth quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time.
Now I will turn the call over to Andrew Wamser, Treasurer and Vice President of Investor Relations for AutoNation.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to AutoNation's fourth quarter and full year 2015 conference call and webcast. Leading our call today will be Mike Jackson, our Chairman, CEO and President; Cheryl Miller, our Chief Financial Of
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to AutoNation's fourth quarter and full year 2015 conference call and webcast. Leading our call today will be Mike Jackson, our Chairman, CEO and President; Cheryl Miller, our Chief Financial Officer; Bill Berman, our Chief Operating Officer; and Jon Ferrando, our Executive Vice President responsible for M&A. Following their remarks, we will open up the call for questions, Robert Quartaro and I will also be available via phone following the call to address any additional questions that you may have.
Before we begin, let me read our brief statement regarding forward-looking comments. Certain statements and information on this call may constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the federal Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Such forward-looking statements involve risks, which may cause the actual results or performance to differ materially from such forward-looking statements. Additional discussions of factors that could cause actual results to differ materially are contained in our press release issued earlier today and our SEC filings, including our most recent Annual Report on Form 10-K and subsequent quarterly reports on Form 10-Q and current reports on Form 8-K. Certain non-GAAP financial measures as defined under SEC rules will be discussed on this call. Reconciliations are provided in our press release and on our website located at investors.autonation.com.
And now, I'll the call over to AutoNation's Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President, Mike Jackson.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Today, we reported adjusted EPS from continuing operations of $0.96, a 6% decrease on a -- as compared to EPS from continuing operations of $1.02 for the same period in the prior year. For the full year, adjuste
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Today, we reported adjusted EPS from continuing operations of $0.96, a 6% decrease on a -- as compared to EPS from continuing operations of $1.02 for the same period in the prior year. For the full year, adjusted EPS from continuing operations was $3.98, up 14% over prior year.
Fourth quarter 2015 revenue totaled $5.3 billion compared to $5 billion in the year-ago period, an increase of 6% driven by stronger performance in all our business sectors. Total gross profit was $812 million compared to $784 million in the year-ago period, an increase of 4%. Operating income was $200 million compared to $227 million in the year-ago period, a decrease of 12%. In the fourth quarter, AutoNation's retail new vehicle unit sales increased 4% overall or 1% on a same-store basis.
The fourth quarter industry sales environment was more pushed than pull, resulting in significant new and used vehicle margin declines on a combined basis of $217 per vehicle retailed, which is 11% lower than the fourth quarter of 2014. During the quarter, we experienced particular weakness in premium luxury, which had a significant impact on our fourth quarter financial results. We have begun and will continue through the first quarter,  take the necessary steps to align our cost, inventory and pricing strategy to the current market.
Revenue for the full year was $20.9 billion, up 9% over prior year, total gross profit was $3.3 billion compared to $3 billion in the year-ago period, an increase of 9%. Operating income for the full year was $873 million, an increase of 6% over prior year. Our assumption for 2016 industry new vehicle unit sales is above $17 million for the year.
I now turn over to our Chief Financial Officer, Cheryl Miller.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike, and good morning, everyone. For the fourth quarter, we reported adjusted net income from continuing operations of $107 million or $0.96 per share versus net income of $117 million or $1.02 per share during the fourth quarter of 2014, a 6%
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike, and good morning, everyone. For the fourth quarter, we reported adjusted net income from continuing operations of $107 million or $0.96 per share versus net income of $117 million or $1.02 per share during the fourth quarter of 2014, a 6% decrease on a per share basis. Our fourth quarter 2015 results exclude a noncash impairment charge of $9.6 million after-tax or $0.09 per share related to the franchise rights asset of our Volkswagen stores. There were no adjustments to net income in the fourth quarter for the prior year.
Revenues during the quarter increased $292 million or 6% compared to the prior-year and gross profit improved $29 million or 4%. SG&A as a percentage of gross profit was 70% for the quarter, which represents a 210 basis point increase compared to the year-ago period due to the gross profit pressure in the fourth quarter, SG&A as a percentage of gross profit did not benefit from the normal seasonal strength in premium luxury vehicle sales.
As we continue to adjust our cost structure to be a current environment, our SG&A as a percentage of growth, is expected to remain under pressure.
The provision for income tax in the quarter was $61.3 million or 38.5%. Net new vehicle floorplan was the benefit of $15.1 million, which was relatively flat compared to the fourth quarter of 2014 as increased floor plan balances were largely offset by higher sales and increased floorplan assistance per unit.
Floor plan debt increased sequentially, approximately $523 million during the fourth quarter to $3.7 billion at quarter-end primarily due to increased inventory balances.
Non-vehicle interest expense increased to $26.5 million compared to $22.1 million in the fourth quarter of 2014. The $4.4 million increase in interest expense was driven by the issuance of our senior unsecured notes in September, which had higher rate than our revolving credit facility as well as higher average debt balances. The increased senior notes rate was partially offset by lower interest rate associated with our credit facility refinancing of issuance of our commercial paper program. At the end of December, we had $2.4 billion of non-vehicle debt, an increase of $162 million compared to September 30, 2015. Non-vehicle debt includes $600 million of outstanding commercial paper borrowings. At the end of December, we had no amounts drawn under our revolving credit facility. As a consequence, our non-vehicle debt mix was approximately 75% fixed and 25% floating. I'll also note that we have no material debt maturities until late 2017.
For the full year 2015, we repurchased 3.9 million shares or $235 million at an average price of $60.49 per share. As of January 26, AutoNation had approximately $296 million of board authorization remaining for share repurchase, and there were approximately 111 million shares outstanding. This does not include the dilutive impact of stock options.
Our leverage ratio increased the 2.3x at the end of Q4 compared to 2.2x at the end of Q3. The leverage ratio was 2.1x on a net debt basis, including used floor plan availability and our covenant limit is 3.75x.
Capital expenditures were $75.3 million for the quarter. Capital expenditures are on an accrual basis excluding operating lease buyouts and related asset sales. Our quarter end cash balance was $74 million, which combined with our additional borrowing capacity, resulted in total liquidity of $1.7 billion at the end of December. We continue to use our revolving credit facility as a liquidity backstop for borrowings under our commercial paper program. As I mentioned a moment ago, we had $600 million of outstanding commercial paper at quarter end, which in effect, reduces our available liquidity to $1.1 billion.
Looking forward, we are focused on aligning our cost structure to better adjust to current market conditions and continuing to prudently allocate capital.
Now let me turn it over to our Chief Operating Officer, Phil Berman.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Cheryl, and good morning. My comments today will be on a same-store basis as compared to the prior-year unless noted otherwise. Gross profit for variable operations was $450 million, down 4%. variable growth was $3,350 on a per-vehicle retail basi
componenttext:
Thanks, Cheryl, and good morning. My comments today will be on a same-store basis as compared to the prior-year unless noted otherwise. Gross profit for variable operations was $450 million, down 4%. variable growth was $3,350 on a per-vehicle retail basis, a decrease of $125 or 4%. New and used same-store unit volume was flat compared to the fourth quarter of 2014. New vehicle revenue for the quarter was $3 billion, an increase of $61 million or 2%. We retailed 82,900 units, an increase of 1%.
New vehicle gross profit was $2,018 on a per-vehicle retail basis, which was down 10% compared to the same period a year ago.
In the fourth quarter, we experienced a push rather than pull environment. We saw margin compression, particularly in Premium Luxury segment. This offset that seasonal sequential increase in PVRs we typically expect in the fourth quarter. Coupled with the margin pressure in the fourth quarter, we also began to see a slowdown in Texas due to collapsing energy prices, which are hurting the local economy.
In Texas, the new and used unit sales were down compared to the fourth quarter of 24, 2014. In Florida, we continue to experience growth across the state, new and used units were up for the quarter compared to the fourth quarter of 2014. As Mike mentioned earlier, we are taking steps to align our costs, inventory and pricing strategy with the current market conditions.
Used vehicle retail revenue for the quarter was $1 billion, an increase of $22 million or 2% compared to the period a year ago. Used vehicle retail were down 2% year-over-year at $52,000. Used unit gross profit was $1,436 on a per-vehicle retail basis, a decrease of $246 or 15%. As of year-end, approximately 6% of our and what are was not available to sale due to open recalls. The held inventory represents less than 2% of our new vehicle inventory and approximately 16% of our used vehicle inventory. As we've stated in the third quarter, we saw an impact in sales due to policy. We continue to implement systems and processes in support of our efforts to ensure no vehicle with an open recall this retailed. We continue to lead long-term safety benefit for our customers to far outweigh any short-term impact our results and further support the AutoNation brand promise.
Customer financial services gross profit was $1,556 on a per-vehicle retail basis, an increase of $109 or 8%. Total gross profit for customer financial services was $210 million, it was up $14 million or 7% compared to the period a year ago.
In the quarter, customer care revenue was $751 million, an increase of $28 million or 4%. Customer care gross profit was $326 million, an increase of $24 million or 8%. Customer pay gross was $129 million, up 9%; warranty gross was $66 million, up 7%; collision gross was $31 million, up 11%.
Finally, I'd like to welcome the Honda associates at AutoNation family, and thank all of our over 26,000 associates for the hard work and dedication.
I'd now turn the call over to John Fernando, Executive Vice President responsible for M&A.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. In the fourth quarter of 2015, we completed the previously announced acquisitions of 13 stores, in Georgia, Alabama and Tennessee and a Honda store in the Seattle Belleview market. For the full year 2015, AutoN
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. In the fourth quarter of 2015, we completed the previously announced acquisitions of 13 stores, in Georgia, Alabama and Tennessee and a Honda store in the Seattle Belleview market. For the full year 2015, AutoNation completed the acquisition of 22 stores generating approximately $1 billion in annual revenue. In the first quarter of 2016, we are on track to complete previously announced acquisition of the 12 store [indiscernible] group in Texas, which generates approximately $800 million in annual revenue. As of today, our store portfolio numbers, 342 franchises and 254 stores in 15 states representing 35 manufactured brands. These numbers will grow to 373 franchises and 266 stores upon completion of the [indiscernible] acquisition.
Looking forward, we will continue to actively pursue acquisitions and new store opportunities with a focus on enhancing brand representation within our existing markets and markets that could be supported by our existing management infrastructure. We will continue to be selective and prudent with our capital with a focus on investing to produce strong returns and long-term shareholder value.
I will now turn it back to Mike Jackson.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. 2015 was a historic year for AutoNation. We celebrate the sale of our 10 millionth vehicle. Implement recall policy. We upward 51 franchises with approximately $1 billion in annual revenue and we built our brand and kicked off our drive t
componenttext: Thank you, John. 2015 was a historic year for AutoNation. We celebrate the sale of our 10 millionth vehicle. Implement recall policy. We upward 51 franchises with approximately $1 billion in annual revenue and we built our brand and kicked off our drive think campaign from coast-to-coast. We're now happy to take any or all questions.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Brett Hoselton on with KeyBanc.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Irena [indiscernible] on for Brett Hoselton. My question for you is on the new vehicle segment. It appears the underperformance is all in November and some improvement is evident in December. I'm wondering if you can tell us what happened in Novem
componenttext: This is Irena [indiscernible] on for Brett Hoselton. My question for you is on the new vehicle segment. It appears the underperformance is all in November and some improvement is evident in December. I'm wondering if you can tell us what happened in November and what do you do differently in December to get some improvement. And just coincidentally, it at the year November is when you closed the large acquisition, did that have anything to do with it or is that something else?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, this is Mike Jackson. First, I think comparisons to the industry reporting calendar and our GAAP results are difficult to do, so overall, on an industry calendar, we were plus 3% same-store sales for the quarter, and we really don't know what t
componenttext: Yes. Well, this is Mike Jackson. First, I think comparisons to the industry reporting calendar and our GAAP results are difficult to do, so overall, on an industry calendar, we were plus 3% same-store sales for the quarter, and we really don't know what the industry was at retail, but something higher than that, I think, is reasonable to assume. We were overweighted in Texas and in premium luxury compared to the industry and that would be the explanation for any GAAP in our performance. And as far as the acquisition being disruptive, no impact whatsoever.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is Michael Montani with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question is Michael Montani with Evercore ISI.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess what I wanted to ask about was the decline in gross profit per unit that we've seen, is this symptomatic of a need to reset gross profit per unit from $2,000 to $1,500 or $1,600, say? Or is this more of an imbalance in supply and demand that can b
componenttext: I guess what I wanted to ask about was the decline in gross profit per unit that we've seen, is this symptomatic of a need to reset gross profit per unit from $2,000 to $1,500 or $1,600, say? Or is this more of an imbalance in supply and demand that can be worked through? Is there anything you can point to what history that can help us kind of see how this could work itself out?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think anytime the industry moves from a period of exceptional growth, 6 years of it, to beginning to plateau and we see significantly higher inventories year-over-year, that's going to put pressure on growth. So we've taken steps to begin to bring
componenttext: Well, I think anytime the industry moves from a period of exceptional growth, 6 years of it, to beginning to plateau and we see significantly higher inventories year-over-year, that's going to put pressure on growth. So we've taken steps to begin to bring our inventories in line. Obviously, there's a lot of lead time on our orders, but we'll see some progress in the first quarter, but it will probably take the second quarter. But even if we do that, it's the industry overproduces and keeps inventory at a high level, that means the overall environment is still very difficult and very competitive even though we may have our house in order within this. It certainly puts us in a better position, but it's not a full answer. So that remains to be seen. I think if you go back to the period of 2000 through 2006, the industry plateaued at an average of 17 million units a year. But clearly, overproduced and had high inventories, which put tremendous pressure on manufacturers, resale values and retailers for growth. So I really hope we don't repeat that history and that we go a new way this time.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And if I could just ask for a little clarity on the inventory build year-over-year in days or percentage terms and also on the gross profit pressure. Could you just parse out for us a little bit how that looks by segment in terms of premium versus
componenttext: Right. And if I could just ask for a little clarity on the inventory build year-over-year in days or percentage terms and also on the gross profit pressure. Could you just parse out for us a little bit how that looks by segment in terms of premium versus midline import and domestics, just to help us quantify?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: My, this is Bill Berman. First off, on the first quarter basis of this year, we're going to be approximately 13 days higher in our days supply inventory. When you look at total units, it was about 14,000 additional units off of what's right now relatively
componenttext: My, this is Bill Berman. First off, on the first quarter basis of this year, we're going to be approximately 13 days higher in our days supply inventory. When you look at total units, it was about 14,000 additional units off of what's right now relatively a flat marketplace. As far as making it out by segment, we've seen pressure primarily on our premium luxuries, a little bit on import and domestic for the most part is inline.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question, John Murphy with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question, John Murphy with Bank of America.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a first question kind of follow-up on the inventory. If you look at the aggregate in the industry and the D3 and even the J3, it was a small, very tiny increase on an absolute basis year-over-year in the fourth quarter, premium luxury seems to be whe
componenttext: Just a first question kind of follow-up on the inventory. If you look at the aggregate in the industry and the D3 and even the J3, it was a small, very tiny increase on an absolute basis year-over-year in the fourth quarter, premium luxury seems to be where the focus is. So I was curious, I know you can't give specific companies, but as we look at this, I mean, you see that ill actions of 2000 and 2006 that some in the D3 were committing really emerging here? Or is somewhat we're seeing at the end of last year and beginning of this year more a function of what's going on [indiscernible] in the premium luxury and your comments to try to make sure it doesn't reemerge into D3?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's more of the second. I think domestics are well-positioned to exceed in 2016. All the -- almost all the excess inventories in cars, not in trucks, to the extent that you have strength in trucks and can produce more trucks, you want to thrive i
componenttext: I think it's more of the second. I think domestics are well-positioned to exceed in 2016. All the -- almost all the excess inventories in cars, not in trucks, to the extent that you have strength in trucks and can produce more trucks, you want to thrive in 2016. I think Sergio's decision to switch over factories from car production to truck production shows you the sense that the consumer has that they are totally committed to cheap gas and to trucks, it's really become a strategic question, not a tactical question. So wherever you will stand on trucks is your position of strength in the marketplace. So that's very different than 2000 in a domestic -- from a starting point, the domestics are in a very good position. I would've hoped during this period of growth, the industry could've gotten some of its benchmarks more accurate, so that when we have a GAAP conversation versus an industry conversation, it could be more meaningful. Here, I point to the obsolete industry calendar that moves days around willy-nilly and a -- it was originally done because the sales report is in a digital age, whether the months end, they should close the month digitally. I also have a long-standing issue with the days supply calculation in that fleet sales were counted in retail selling rate, which is a major distortion. So pointing to industry figures to try to figure out what's going on is not always helpful and making a comparison then to GAAP figures get particularly difficult. So those issues are not resolved. They still sit there. But I think, the principal point, the industry is in a much better shape today than it was in 2000, both from a structural point of view and that we're at the beginning of this plateau and there's still time to adjust. There's a particular overhang in premium luxury, which will take some time to work through.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then a second question on capital allocating. Obviously, the biggest thing that's changed in really the December and current period is that your stock was down about 35%, so it's 35% cheaper and looks fairly attractive at least f
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then a second question on capital allocating. Obviously, the biggest thing that's changed in really the December and current period is that your stock was down about 35%, so it's 35% cheaper and looks fairly attractive at least from where I sit, and I'm just curious, as you think about cap allocation in 2016, have you seen sort of a similar adjustment and the private market on acquisitions where multiples and valuations have come down fairily significantly? Or as we look at '16 and if your stock doesn't recover meaningfully from here, I mean, does this make your stock much more attractive relative to the acquisitions if we see buying back more of your own stock as opposed to making acquisitions?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So John, our basic philosophy remains unchanged. We first invest in our existing stores, our digital capability and our brand, that's our first call on capital, that will remain. And then we look at the opportunity to purchase our own company through shar
componenttext: So John, our basic philosophy remains unchanged. We first invest in our existing stores, our digital capability and our brand, that's our first call on capital, that will remain. And then we look at the opportunity to purchase our own company through share repurchase versus acquisitions that fit with our long-term plan and, obviously, then, there's a competition between the return of buying our own stock and what we can buy in the marketplace. The marketplace as far as acquisition usually takes longer for sellers to come to any new reality. So I think it's too soon to expect any seismic shift there. So that would make the decision at a moment a bit easier is, which way to go and I will rest on our track record that we've done a very good job on capital allocation over the last 15 years.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sounds good. And just lastly on SG&A flexibility. I mean, If we see this pressure persists for a couple of quarters, what kind of buckets or actions in SG&A do you think you could really, sort of, react reasonably quickly and may be versus even longer ove
componenttext: Sounds good. And just lastly on SG&A flexibility. I mean, If we see this pressure persists for a couple of quarters, what kind of buckets or actions in SG&A do you think you could really, sort of, react reasonably quickly and may be versus even longer over longer-term time frame?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So john, we're still forecasting market over $17 million. So we still need the infrastructure and the staffing to perform at that level. However, since we are not forecasting extraordinary growth in 2016, we will adjust inventories and over time, that wil
componenttext: So john, we're still forecasting market over $17 million. So we still need the infrastructure and the staffing to perform at that level. However, since we are not forecasting extraordinary growth in 2016, we will adjust inventories and over time, that will give us more control over the balance between -- to be able to make a decision between volume and price. Your heavy on inventory, you can make a decision, you just have to until you find the point that the product moves. Second, we can adjust marketing. Again, we're spending assuming growth. It didn't happen, that's really my responsibility for the fourth quarter, but now we will adjust and that can be brought in line relatively quickly. Joe, you want to make any other comment on cost?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, I think, as you know, in this type of decline is margin pressure. So we watch the things that need to be there to support volume. But, of course, as you know, based on our track record of running lean, we're going to evaluate everything. So I t
componenttext: Yes, John, I think, as you know, in this type of decline is margin pressure. So we watch the things that need to be there to support volume. But, of course, as you know, based on our track record of running lean, we're going to evaluate everything. So I think the biggest buckets, if you look at the quarter compensation, it looks pretty well. So I think we did a good job there. Marketing as Mike mentioned, we're reassessing in Q1 in light of the current environment and then picking through the different cost buckets to make sure we're focused on pure investment and things that add value for today and for the long-term. So we'll go through, kind of, the heavy grinding in all of the other buckets to make sure we're as tight as possible heading into Q2.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is Irish Jane with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Next question is Irish Jane with Morgan Stanley.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions. First, when we look at the blended GPU, that is still pretty close to record levels and obviously, SNR is a big piece of it now. Is that also something that is driving more aggressive behavior on new and used vehicles from deal
componenttext: Just a couple of questions. First, when we look at the blended GPU, that is still pretty close to record levels and obviously, SNR is a big piece of it now. Is that also something that is driving more aggressive behavior on new and used vehicles from dealers? And the reason I ask is beyond -- if you think beyond near-term makes and inventory issues and assuming those can reverse, couldn't we see a continuation of this new and used GPs used from here on.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paresh, it's Bill. Our CFS gross profits definitely strong and they do weigh to our decisions on how to we accept deals, to Mike's point, try to find balance between our volume and pricing, so it does play into it. But it is not a contributing factor to t
componenttext: Paresh, it's Bill. Our CFS gross profits definitely strong and they do weigh to our decisions on how to we accept deals, to Mike's point, try to find balance between our volume and pricing, so it does play into it. But it is not a contributing factor to the compression that we're seeing on TDR's right now.

componenttext: Understood. And a quick follow-up on F&I. We have the Honda dealer of last year with CFPB. Has there been any impact on F&I [indiscernible] transaction? Are you seeing a similar level of push from vendors to adopt that solution?

componenttext: Our Honda stores are performing extremely well. And like Mike said, our last collecting, what Honda did is [indiscernible] enjoined the marketplace in his perform well both to the consumer as well as to our stores. There's been talk of others, but nothing concrete.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I next question is from Brian Sponheimer of the and Company.
componenttext: I next question is from Brian Sponheimer of the and Company.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just I guess to start, Mike, when you called out some of the industry problems, what's been the reaction, particularly with some of the automakers that are having some of the inventory issues to what you've said. Are they aware of it? Or are they buying t
componenttext: Just I guess to start, Mike, when you called out some of the industry problems, what's been the reaction, particularly with some of the automakers that are having some of the inventory issues to what you've said. Are they aware of it? Or are they buying to it as we seen 15 years ago, the D3 having that issue?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it's very interesting. I expressed my plateau point of view on CNBC the first week of January and then got on the plane and went to the Detroit motor show. I would say, the overall discussion agreed that our 60 years of rapid growth are over, but the
componenttext: No, it's very interesting. I expressed my plateau point of view on CNBC the first week of January and then got on the plane and went to the Detroit motor show. I would say, the overall discussion agreed that our 60 years of rapid growth are over, but the industry is plateauing at a very high, very acceptable level and no one is really saying, "this thing is going to blowby $18 million to $18.5 million or something within the industry." I know there's some others out there that have a point if you that that's going to happen. If that were to happen, I can tell you this, it would take significant price action that would be pulling forward future business from my point of view. Now unfortunately, every executive is very confident and optimistic about their position in the marketplace and they have plans for growth in 2016. So if you add up everyone's individual plan, you have this classic situation that everyone's going to take share, but that means set the plants to run to go out and achieve that. So while they're being conservative and disciplined in saying, "the total market is probably mid-'17, plus or minus 100,000 units, we'll take that right away," we're going to take a bigger piece of the pie. So I think that's then going to be incumbent upon retailers to really push back where appropriate and say, "that's more than this marketplace is going to take, particularly on the car side," to the extent that you can increase production on trucks, that's fine. But it's going to be substitution for cars, it's not incremental business. I think that's a solid plan. I think if retailers push back on very aggressive production plans and by the way, we're being given very aggressive stairstep targets also, which again, indicate that individually, they're planning for significant growth. So the ball is kicked, debate is underway and I'm hoping the industry can manage it successfully because the challenge for the industry, I feel, over the next several years is we can have multiple years above '17 with the pent-up demand that's out there. But in a plateau new vehicle market, can we grow earnings and the quality of earnings? Or are we going to have a share fight that results in ruin these incentives for the manufacturers and for retailers? I think that's sort of aligned we're trying to walk down at the moment.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate all that color. I guess my second question is a little more short-term in nature. There's a particular OEM that 3 years ago, went from 36 month lease to a 39-month lease. So theoretically, you're going to see more trade-ins come in starting i
componenttext: I appreciate all that color. I guess my second question is a little more short-term in nature. There's a particular OEM that 3 years ago, went from 36 month lease to a 39-month lease. So theoretically, you're going to see more trade-ins come in starting in February, March or April, how much is that needed to clean up this inventory issue on the car side?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think first on the consumer's commitment to pay for their car loans whether it's used to finance, it's unwavering. I see absolutely no signs of difficulties in auto finance. I think it's all being run very prudently and in a disciplined way. So no
componenttext: Well, I think first on the consumer's commitment to pay for their car loans whether it's used to finance, it's unwavering. I see absolutely no signs of difficulties in auto finance. I think it's all being run very prudently and in a disciplined way. So no alarm bells there. There are, I think, 1 million more vehicles coming off of these this year than the prior year. That doesn't necessarily mean all those individuals are going to go into new cars. They could go into CPO or something else. So you can't just add that to the top line in my opinion.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Your next question is Rod Lache with Deutsche Bank.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that you guys have done a phenomenal job of adjusting all kinds of scenarios that have come at you over the past few years. But I'd love to hear how you feel from your perspective, how consumers would be broadly affected by a scenario with pa
componenttext: I appreciate that you guys have done a phenomenal job of adjusting all kinds of scenarios that have come at you over the past few years. But I'd love to hear how you feel from your perspective, how consumers would be broadly affected by a scenario with passenger car traded values falling. You did say, obviously, the market today is trucks, but passenger cars are higher percentage of the market years ago, so I would imagine they were higher percentage of trade-ins. How does that affect them? How do you see that affecting your volumes, margins and deals that you're putting together when you do take trades?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think the biggest threat to used car values are additional incentives in the manufacturers or additional discounts from us, that's the big picture issue. So it's very interesting, our fourth quarter performance where by manufacturers increasing incen
componenttext: So I think the biggest threat to used car values are additional incentives in the manufacturers or additional discounts from us, that's the big picture issue. So it's very interesting, our fourth quarter performance where by manufacturers increasing incentives by $250 a car; us, increasing our discount by $220 a car, that had an immediate impact in our used car values. And then we had to discount, anything that was relatively new versus the new vehicle in the showroom floor. So it's a double impact. It impacted our new vehicle gross margin, it impacted our used vehicle gross margin. So that's the biggest issue and that's my greatest concern about overproduction. And you can say, Mike, what you care for manufacturers increased their incentives significantly, we'll just sell more cars. Well, it pulls the rug out from underneath the value of my used car inventory. And also to your point, it really disappoints your existing owner base, your most loyal customers because you depreciated ultimately the value of the trade in. So it's really a lose-lose, it's a lose in the short-term and lose long-term. And I really don't want to see incentives beyond the manufacturer level. They're about 10% of suggested retail price at the moment. So we're approaching double digits and I really hope we don't go beyond that. Now to your point of mix, this mix adjustment, cars versus trucks, has been going on. So it's not a shock. It's been -- we've gone from 45% trucks a few years ago to 60% trucks in the month of December. It's been a journey. There's been adjustments along the way. So I think that's more big in the cake at the moment than a new development. It's more where our incentives going? Where our inventories production going? And what will that need to resale value is my #1 concern?

componenttext: You've seen some ABS widening and that's a result of just some broader widening in the bond market and certainly, that's around the state that they play in, but I would say, not everybody funds in ABS. So there's a lot of people balance new funds particularly, if you look at leasing, not funds on that basis and they have broader large balance sheets for their blended funding rates. I would say, it's one factor. You've seen it more and subprimes than in regular and I don't think it's going to be a material driver of the rates provided to customers.

componenttext: And I think the percentage of -- in the OEMs post. So I would say that place of widening today that you see in certain tranches and subprime ABS is much more impactful than it would have been back in 2008, 2009 intentionally because they no longer wanted to be reliant on that type of funding source solely.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think Texas is about 24%, 25% of our business for 2016. So that's a significant overweight. As you know, our 3 big states are California, Texas and Florida. Florida is absolutely booming. Texas is under stress. We had a decline in Texas on same-store sa
componenttext: I think Texas is about 24%, 25% of our business for 2016. So that's a significant overweight. As you know, our 3 big states are California, Texas and Florida. Florida is absolutely booming. Texas is under stress. We had a decline in Texas on same-store sales, units of 2%, but I'll also tell you, it took a lot more discounts to get that done in Texas, so it had a significant impact on the bottom line.

componenttext: And then the last question for you, a little bit on the used side and the recall initiative. Naturally, as expected, that is having some impact on your volume. Wondering, as you're going through it, what are you funding now. And how is it tracking relative to your expectations? Is it better or worse? You didn't have a whole lot anticipated in new in terms of long-term cost for implications, what are you learning as you go through this?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in our recall policy, you see, it's relatively modest, they have no impact on new vehicles and we were already repairing new vehicles. So that's not an issue, it's a significant impact on name. Now just to discuss the issue for a moment, I think the au
componenttext: So in our recall policy, you see, it's relatively modest, they have no impact on new vehicles and we were already repairing new vehicles. So that's not an issue, it's a significant impact on name. Now just to discuss the issue for a moment, I think the auto industry really had some credibility issues, it has to face up to everything from horrific recalls we've had with significant loss of life to credibility issues around the Volkswagen situation. So we sit there and say, what can we do on our part to make it better? Well preowned, this is a significant issue, on any given day, 15% of our inventory had open recalls. Now let me be clear, these are not wrong tire pressure, sticker isn't on the core or some other little minor item, it doesn't have an owners manual. That's on new cars when they're first released, you get the sticker issue or the owners manual issue, you have 1 page missing. These are significant safety recall. And we feel that time has passed that it's appropriate to take a vehicle and trade with a significant safety recall and turned around the next day and sell it to a consumer. So we're the only one that's done it. We think it's a brand attribute. We will work to make it a brand attribute in 2016 and we feel in the long-term, it will be a tremendous advantage to us. In the meantime, it is very disruptive to our used car business because we see no way to get it below 15%. There's new recalls arriving every day and we have to increase inventory to get to the same point and, I think, we're in the front line availability. And at the same time, we have to then work very hard to get the vehicles repaired as constantly as possible. So it remains a disruptive issue. I would say, if I look at our declines [indiscernible] gross for the fourth quarter on used vehicle, I would put the majority of it to higher incentives from the manufacturers and higher new vehicle discounts from us. But recall disruption remains part of it, and probably will continue for the first half of the year until -- while we get it all sorted out.

Are you fully transacting online now? And then along those lines, has there been any negative impact from your reduction in third-party relationships throughout the year?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we didn't have much discussion about it because it's a complete success. We made the pivot last year away from third-party lead providers who required a substantial additional discount in order to get the business and were expensive to do business wi
componenttext: Yes, we didn't have much discussion about it because it's a complete success. We made the pivot last year away from third-party lead providers who required a substantial additional discount in order to get the business and were expensive to do business with. The third-party lead providers who we stayed with and are now about 8% of our business overall. We have wonderful new partnership where we're allowed to bring our brand into their sites, which we -- and that is a condition of doing business with us. And so that is a huge step forward. And as I said, we've gone from trending towards 15% of the business with third parties. In a couple of more years, it would have been 20%, now it's going in the other direction and that gives us more resources to go into our brand. We now generate fully 25% of our business from AutoNation sites, which is a spectacular success. The customers like the ability to be able to transact on the site. We still have capabilities that we're adding step-by-step that continue to rollout. I think the most difficult piece remains the documentation that may push into 2017. There's different pieces of it that we can get done but regulatory change to that it completely done. So that's probably rolling into 2017, everything else we talked about, we expect to have operational in 2016. There is a cost to just continue with this level of regional intensity, I have no issue with that. But I don't see -- I think as said this already in the fourth quarter, as far as investment in digital, we probably hit peak. We'll run at that in 2016, and after that, be able to go down to more of a maintenance level. But you can check with me a year from now on that when we get the final plan on how we're going to tackle documentation.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttextpreview: So the $100 million was what we were going to do. I forgot which year it was '14, '15, I don't remember exactly. And it was a combination of what we are going to invest in the brand that we could attract traffic to our sites and the digital capability [in
componenttext: So the $100 million was what we were going to do. I forgot which year it was '14, '15, I don't remember exactly. And it was a combination of what we are going to invest in the brand that we could attract traffic to our sites and the digital capability [indiscernible] That was a combination. So on in 2015, the band was strong enough that we could walk away from third-party lead providers and have the traffic come to our sites and then other piece of the puzzle was to invest in our digital capability once they came to our sites, they were happy with the experience. So there, we're declaring victory. And as far as exactly where we are on that $100 million, I think we're probably through that. But we'll continue to have investments in '16. We already said in the marketing side, we'll adjust our spend this year versus last year, so that's part of it. And on digital, we'll probably run at the same level as '15 without an increase.

componenttext: Okay. That's very helpful color. And then maybe some of the GM and, obviously, VW, I don't think there's fix out there yet, but how much more gas is in that pack for recalls to help push growth in PNS going forward?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Bill. First of all, on parts and service, we see strong growth in parts and service. As far as it relates to recalls, Mike talked about it earlier, everyday, we get additional recalls coming in. You just heard about Dakota, out of 5 million additi
componenttext: This is Bill. First of all, on parts and service, we see strong growth in parts and service. As far as it relates to recalls, Mike talked about it earlier, everyday, we get additional recalls coming in. You just heard about Dakota, out of 5 million additional cars to the recalls for the airbags, Ford just announced a large recall on Ranger trucks. So we see no slowdown in the amount of cars being recalled, it's just moving away from the ignition switches and initial Dakota airbag to a more of a broad spectrum of units and manufacturers. VW, correct, there is no fix that's been called out right now, but that represents a very small percentage of our business, less than 1%. So there will be no real impact to us on that input. Parts and service will continue to remain strong.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That was our last question. Somebody said it earlier in a statement, pulling our ability to adapt to circumstances, how we demonstrate that in the past, we will do that again. Can't tell you exactly how long it will take, but it's underway. We still total
componenttext: That was our last question. Somebody said it earlier in a statement, pulling our ability to adapt to circumstances, how we demonstrate that in the past, we will do that again. Can't tell you exactly how long it will take, but it's underway. We still totally believe in the validity of our diversified model. We're 1/3 domestic, 1/3 Asian and 1/3 premium luxury. Obviously, the domestic business with trucks is as strong as you can imagine and Asian is challenged because fuel economy, which is their strength is not valued by the marketplace at the moment and we have a surprising challenge with premium luxury here in the fourth quarter. We're diversified by business type, we went through all that and we're diversify geographically. Yes, we have a storm in Texas at the moment that will take some time to blow through, but in total, it's an adaptable model and we will do that once again. So thank you for your patience today. Thank you for your very constructive questions and we will look forward to talking to you again in the future. Thank you very much for joining us today.
