componenttext: Disruption. I think that GM just announced plant closing for a couple of weeks. Obviously, there's some but I don't think it compared. Bill, do have any later -- latest information from any manufacturers?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you just called it out, Mike. So General Motors idled 4 factories this morning because of supply constraints. Toyota is supposed to come back online on the 25th with the exception of one model line through the Lexus brand. But all in all, it's going to
componenttext: So you just called it out, Mike. So General Motors idled 4 factories this morning because of supply constraints. Toyota is supposed to come back online on the 25th with the exception of one model line through the Lexus brand. But all in all, it's going to take probably somewhere a little bit less than 100,000 units out of the initial supply coming in. We can more than offset that.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, okay. And I guess, I was surprised to see gross per used unit back up about $200 on a sequential basis from 4Q. Any color there? Is it just sales habits maybe changed to a little bit more normalized pattern during the quarter?
componenttext: Right, okay. And I guess, I was surprised to see gross per used unit back up about $200 on a sequential basis from 4Q. Any color there? Is it just sales habits maybe changed to a little bit more normalized pattern during the quarter?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Mike Jackson. I think there's 2 issues as the manufacturers take new vehicle incentives towards 10% or 9.6% at this point. That has a domino effect into the pricing of used vehicles. And I think we also had an issue with the number of vehicles and
componenttext: This is Mike Jackson. I think there's 2 issues as the manufacturers take new vehicle incentives towards 10% or 9.6% at this point. That has a domino effect into the pricing of used vehicles. And I think we also had an issue with the number of vehicles and length of time that we were holding vehicles waiting for parts on recall. We've now made a decision that if there's absolutely no parts in sight, that we will wholesale auction that vehicle with full disclosure. So as I talked about earlier, that should help in that issue over time.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So you're not expecting anything again quite like the hit that you experienced in the fourth quarter on the used side from a gross profit per unit...
componenttext: Okay. So you're not expecting anything again quite like the hit that you experienced in the fourth quarter on the used side from a gross profit per unit...

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, do you have anything to add there?
componenttext: Bill, do you have anything to add there?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We've -- like you talked about earlier, Mike, we started auctioning off the excess supply of recalled vehicles that had no fix in sight. We've cleared most of that out between the fourth quarter of last year and the first quarter of this year, so we d
componenttext: No. We've -- like you talked about earlier, Mike, we started auctioning off the excess supply of recalled vehicles that had no fix in sight. We've cleared most of that out between the fourth quarter of last year and the first quarter of this year, so we don't have quite as much exposure as we had before. And to Mike's point, as there's continued incentives and pressure on the front end of the new vehicles, used vehicle are much more attractive on a pricing point. I mean, we're able to take advantage of that. So we should be able to remain with our gross from this last quarter.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will be from Colin Langan from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question will be from Colin Langan from UBS.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Any color on the trajectory of new vehicle margin? Do you think they start to improve throughout the year? Sort of how should we think about the cadence, given the issues that we started in Q4? Have they started to alleviate within the Luxury business? Or
componenttext: Any color on the trajectory of new vehicle margin? Do you think they start to improve throughout the year? Sort of how should we think about the cadence, given the issues that we started in Q4? Have they started to alleviate within the Luxury business? Or is there going to be a headwind for the next couple of quarters still?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's a lot of work to do over the next couple of quarters as far as the supply levels for both Premium Luxury and the overall market, which makes it difficult to forecast exactly where new vehicle margins will be. I will observe though with our
componenttext: I think there's a lot of work to do over the next couple of quarters as far as the supply levels for both Premium Luxury and the overall market, which makes it difficult to forecast exactly where new vehicle margins will be. I will observe though with our efforts in F&I, our deterioration on same-store debt [ph] basis was only $21 on the total vehicle margin. So again, we've managed that very well. Bill, anything to add?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: The one thing I would add out there, Mike, is there is additional revenue that we do recognize in gross that comes in the form of ad credits from floorplan [ph] credits, and those are constantly changing between the OEMs. So you're looking in the aggregat
componenttext: The one thing I would add out there, Mike, is there is additional revenue that we do recognize in gross that comes in the form of ad credits from floorplan [ph] credits, and those are constantly changing between the OEMs. So you're looking in the aggregate, we've actually had some solid growth there.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And any color on parts and services that was up 5% on a same-store basis? Is that sustainable through the year? And any color within that, how much recalls are helping or is that now a headwind at all within that number now that you had a record y
componenttext: Got it. And any color on parts and services that was up 5% on a same-store basis? Is that sustainable through the year? And any color within that, how much recalls are helping or is that now a headwind at all within that number now that you had a record year in the last couple of years? How should we think about that going forward?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Mike Jackson. 5% is a very satisfactory number and is sustainable. I would say, our recall policy, in that it has slowed the velocity of our used car sales, has ironically probably slowed our amount of reconditioning work that we would be doing on
componenttext: This is Mike Jackson. 5% is a very satisfactory number and is sustainable. I would say, our recall policy, in that it has slowed the velocity of our used car sales, has ironically probably slowed our amount of reconditioning work that we would be doing on internal. So again, as we smooth out all the issues we have around recalls impacting or disrupting our used vehicle sales, that will have a collateral benefit to our service and parts business.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question will be from Mr. Nick Zangler of Stephens.
componenttext: Next question will be from Mr. Nick Zangler of Stephens.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just looking for a little bit more detail on performance among markets, in particular Texas. I'm wondering if you're seeing new sales actually shift to used sales or if both are equally weak. And then I'm wondering if any growth in service and parts could
componenttext: Just looking for a little bit more detail on performance among markets, in particular Texas. I'm wondering if you're seeing new sales actually shift to used sales or if both are equally weak. And then I'm wondering if any growth in service and parts could alleviate that weakness, and then just any commentary on Florida would also be great.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Florida is great. Bill, you want take the rest?
componenttext: Florida is great. Bill, you want take the rest?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mike. In Texas, we're not really seeing a material shift from new vehicle sales to used vehicle sales. The one bright spot that we have seen is there's been more access to vehicles, especially on the used car side, especially when it comes to trucks
componenttext: Sure, Mike. In Texas, we're not really seeing a material shift from new vehicle sales to used vehicle sales. The one bright spot that we have seen is there's been more access to vehicles, especially on the used car side, especially when it comes to trucks. So a lot of the energy workers are getting out of their vehicles. We have access to them at a very attractive pricing. I mean, we're able to turn that back into the marketplace. But on a retail basis, our new and used car business has been affected almost identically.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then I think you guys have said success amongst the OEMs this year would be based on truck production. Just given your visibility into production levels and manufacturing mix, do you feel that OEMs have appropriately shifted production towards
componenttext: Great. And then I think you guys have said success amongst the OEMs this year would be based on truck production. Just given your visibility into production levels and manufacturing mix, do you feel that OEMs have appropriately shifted production towards the truck segment for 2016 and beyond?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Mike Jackson. They are doing everything humanly possible within the constraints of how the plants are laid out. And you see everything from Chrysler completely switching over plants from car production to truck production, to other plants that the
componenttext: This is Mike Jackson. They are doing everything humanly possible within the constraints of how the plants are laid out. And you see everything from Chrysler completely switching over plants from car production to truck production, to other plants that they do it with a shift basis. So believe me, the OEMs clearly know the marketplace has moved dramatically to trucks and are doing everything they humanly possible to get there within the constraints of installed capacity.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will be from Mr. Bret Jordan of Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question will be from Mr. Bret Jordan of Jefferies.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on the trajectory in the quarter. And I guess, as you look at the energy markets and there's been some stabilization and maybe recovery in crude pricing, are you seeing any turn in that market as far as consumer sentiment goes? Or is it still o
componenttext: A question on the trajectory in the quarter. And I guess, as you look at the energy markets and there's been some stabilization and maybe recovery in crude pricing, are you seeing any turn in that market as far as consumer sentiment goes? Or is it still on the bottom?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you're talking about Texas and trying to predict, I have to say, and I hate to be a weatherman, the weather has been so hellacious in Texas, it's hard to separate what are these epic weather events. Like Houston, we just had 20 inches of rain that clos
componenttext: If you're talking about Texas and trying to predict, I have to say, and I hate to be a weatherman, the weather has been so hellacious in Texas, it's hard to separate what are these epic weather events. Like Houston, we just had 20 inches of rain that closed everything. Bill, are we -- what's the view in Houston coming back online?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our stores came back online fully yesterday, Mike.
componenttext: Our stores came back online fully yesterday, Mike.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so it was very disruptive. So it's a little hard to separate at this moment. We'll have to give it a little more time.
componenttext: Yes, so it was very disruptive. So it's a little hard to separate at this moment. We'll have to give it a little more time.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was thinking more along the lines of the energy economy, whether it's stabilizing, is driving any improvement in demand down there, more so than the weather.
componenttext: I was thinking more along the lines of the energy economy, whether it's stabilizing, is driving any improvement in demand down there, more so than the weather.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, you have any insights there?
componenttext: Bill, you have any insights there?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's just kind of like when the prices started to fall. There wasn't a mass exodus. And as prices started to stabilize, you don't see them returning that quickly. There seems to be a lot of volatility in the marketplace, and I think that's definitely
componenttext: Yes. It's just kind of like when the prices started to fall. There wasn't a mass exodus. And as prices started to stabilize, you don't see them returning that quickly. There seems to be a lot of volatility in the marketplace, and I think that's definitely having an effect on the consumer in general. But it's too soon to really give any real guidance on what's happening with the consumer with the slight bump in crude prices.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one other question. I guess you guys have been pretty acquisitive. Are you seeing any shift in seller valuation expectations as the market's plateauing? Are you -- obviously, you did a deal down in Texas. But are you seeing any improving pr
componenttext: Okay. And then one other question. I guess you guys have been pretty acquisitive. Are you seeing any shift in seller valuation expectations as the market's plateauing? Are you -- obviously, you did a deal down in Texas. But are you seeing any improving pricing as you look at transactions?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We see every year a range of price offerings from totally unrealistic, not really for sale to fair pricing. Clearly though, with the opportunity we've had on the share repurchase side, and you're looking at the opportunity you have versus buying your own
componenttext: We see every year a range of price offerings from totally unrealistic, not really for sale to fair pricing. Clearly though, with the opportunity we've had on the share repurchase side, and you're looking at the opportunity you have versus buying your own stock versus doing an acquisition, we are going to be much more selective on the acquisition side saying, hey, we really need a very good fair price here or we're just going to buy our own shares. So that conversation takes place, but the conversations are still going on and we'll have to see if that leads to deals or not.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question will be from Paresh Jain.
componenttext: Next question will be from Paresh Jain.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow up on the need for industry discipline comments. Many investors we talked to find it very hard to believe that industry will be any different this time. Both the OEM and dealer markets are extremely fragmented and all of them expect to
componenttext: I wanted to follow up on the need for industry discipline comments. Many investors we talked to find it very hard to believe that industry will be any different this time. Both the OEM and dealer markets are extremely fragmented and all of them expect to gain share. And then again, the credit environment is extremely supportive. Even captives are rolling out 84-month loan products and you started seeing more used leases as well. So wouldn't volumes typically be the last thing to fall for OEMs or even plateau at this point?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's the movie that we all know very well and you're very appropriately saying every time the industry has faced this test, it's failed. So there we are. That doesn't mean that it can't be different. Big changes have occurred in this industry. I ca
componenttext: Yes, that's the movie that we all know very well and you're very appropriately saying every time the industry has faced this test, it's failed. So there we are. That doesn't mean that it can't be different. Big changes have occurred in this industry. I can remember going into plateau, the OEMs were already losing billions. This time, we've arrived at plateau and they are extremely profitable. So there's new leaders there and maybe the industry can pass the test this time. I would say the conversation has gone pretty well in that we have pretty much agreement in the industry that it's plateaued, step one. Step two, okay, it's taking a little while for them to come to terms with what that means to their company and their plant. We have seen production schedules change. We have seen shifts go down. So I am not totally pessimistic that the industry will go blindly marching forward and pull too much business forward. And when they finally then come to capitulation, it's far uglier than it needs to be. But your point's well taken, I can't argue with it.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. One more follow-up on the cost front. Volumes, in your view, are plateauing. We are in a push versus pull environment, which will keep GPUs under pressure. Those 2 are perhaps not so much in your control but when you think about SG&A and think abo
componenttext: Got it. One more follow-up on the cost front. Volumes, in your view, are plateauing. We are in a push versus pull environment, which will keep GPUs under pressure. Those 2 are perhaps not so much in your control but when you think about SG&A and think about personnel costs in particular, is there enough room to offset that GPU pressure? And when do we start seeing the benefits of the express initiative on cost?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Cheryl?
componenttext: Cheryl?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As you think about it from an SG&A perspective, I'd say one of the bright spots for us and an area that we really focused on when we began to saw -- to see the plateau in the fourth quarter of last year was on compensation. So we've made really good
componenttext: Yes. As you think about it from an SG&A perspective, I'd say one of the bright spots for us and an area that we really focused on when we began to saw -- to see the plateau in the fourth quarter of last year was on compensation. So we've made really good headways on compensation year-over-year. So that's an area that you definitely see that leverage in. Advertising has remained in good order as well. Certainly, when you have gross compression, it does impact, on a percentage basis, some of the store and overhead costs, but we've worked hard to offset that. So if you exclude the hail and the timing of the stock-based compensation, you have the 70% SG&A that remains around our target level. You'd like to see it lower than that, but in this gross pressure environment, it's going to be a little more difficult. I would say digital continues to be a medium- to longer-term exercise so we have made great headway with respect to the third-party lead generators that we previously used. So we brought that below the 9% mark from 15%-plus historically. So continued to see great traction there. And it really helps us deliver on the brand promise. So as we talked about we don't do separate call-outs for the exact impact of digital, but I will tell you that all of the indicators continue to be very positive from those efforts.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, I just wanted to kind of get your thoughts around the progression of the retail SAAR. From, I think, J.D. Power, we've seen it go from about 15.5 last September to about 12.6 in March. It's been sequentially declining every single month along the wa
componenttext: Mike, I just wanted to kind of get your thoughts around the progression of the retail SAAR. From, I think, J.D. Power, we've seen it go from about 15.5 last September to about 12.6 in March. It's been sequentially declining every single month along the way. Just want to sort of understand what you guys are thinking about what might be happening there, kind of the health of the consumer, the economy sort of seems to still be going pretty well. Credit availability, as you mentioned, is still pretty healthy right now.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not so sure the overall economy is as robust as you would have just described it. If I take GDP growth the last 2 -- well, we don't have the first quarter yet but I'm not -- nobody is real bullish on it. There's certainly going to be, I expect,
componenttext: Well, I'm not so sure the overall economy is as robust as you would have just described it. If I take GDP growth the last 2 -- well, we don't have the first quarter yet but I'm not -- nobody is real bullish on it. There's certainly going to be, I expect, less than 2%, significantly less than 2%, and the fourth quarter was tough. You certainly saw the Federal Reserve pull back on its plans to increase interest rates around its concerns on the economy. So I think it's not as strong out there as you might necessarily think, and we're at a high level. Don't forget, we're at a high level for vehicle purchases and is it really realistic to continue those types of increases. I would also point out, I have concerns going into an election year. I have observed in the past, when there's very controversial elections and it looks like we're on the road to having one of those this year, that consumers sometimes hesitate around big purchases, usually pick it up after the election. But leading up to election, it can be a little bit soft. So I think the economy's had a hesitation or a rough patch. We'll have to see if it resumes its stride. That would be very supportive of vehicle sales to get that. So I think my sense that I called out at the beginning of the year and I clearly was the odd man out at the party at the Detroit Motor Show to say, hey, everybody, I don't think things are just going zoom along here was a correct call. And so we're adjusting. I hope the industry adjusts, and it's still an environment where you can be very profitable.

componenttext: So we are not using price to try to get volume. We're more just moving with where the market is. headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to AutoNation's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. Now, we'll turn the call over to Andrew Wamser, Treasurer an
componenttext:
Welcome to AutoNation's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. 
Now, we'll turn the call over to Andrew Wamser, Treasurer and Vice President of Finance for AutoNation. Sir, you may begin.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to AutoNation's Second Quarter 2016 Conference Call and Webcast. Leading our call today will be Mike Jackson, our Chairman, CEO and President; Cheryl Miller, our Chief Financial Officer; Bill
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to AutoNation's Second Quarter 2016 Conference Call and Webcast. 
Leading our call today will be Mike Jackson, our Chairman, CEO and President; Cheryl Miller, our Chief Financial Officer; Bill Berman, our Chief Operating Officer; and Jon Ferrando, our EVP responsible for M&A. 
Following their remarks, we will open up the call for questions. Robert Quartaro and I will also be available by phone following the call to address any additional questions that you may have. 
Before we begin, let me read our brief statement regarding forward-looking comments. Certain statements and information on this call will constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Federal Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Such forward-looking statements involve risks which may cause actual results or performance to differ materially from such forward-looking statements. Additional discussions of factors that could cause actual results to differ materially are contained in our press release issued earlier today and our SEC filings, including our most recent annual report on Form 10-K and subsequent quarterly reports on Form 10-Q and in current reports on Form 8-K. Certain non-GAAP financial measures as defined under SEC rules will be discussed on this call. Reconciliations are provided in our press release and on our website located at investors.autonation.com. 
And now, I'll turn the call over to AutoNation's Chairman, CEO and President, Mike Jackson.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Today, we reported an all-time record earnings per share from continuing operations of $1.08 and 8% increase as compared to EPS from continuing operations of $1 for the same period in the prior year. We achieved
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Today, we reported an all-time record earnings per share from continuing operations of $1.08 and 8% increase as compared to EPS from continuing operations of $1 for the same period in the prior year. We achieved record EPS from continuing operations as we began to see the results of adjusting our cost structure and inventory levels to a plateauing industry sales environment.  We also saw a benefit from our opportunistic capital allocation strategy, which included acquisitions and share repurchase. 
Revenue for the quarter totaled $5.4 billion compared to $5.2 billion in the same period a year ago, an increase of 4%. AutoNation's total retail new vehicle unit sales for the quarter were flat. On a same-store basis, retail new vehicle unit sales were down 5%. 
During the quarter, we continue to see disruption from the Takata airbag recall, which impacted our used vehicle business. Approximately 20% of our used vehicle inventory is currently on hold due to open recalls and approximately, 75% of those vehicles are related to Takata airbags. 
Second quarter was a transitional quarter for certain brands as replacement parts for the Takata airbags became available. We anticipate that our used vehicle on hold. It will peak towards the end of 2016. 
Also in the second half of the year, once the vehicles that have been on hold are repaired and sold, we will recognize compensation related to certain brands paid by the manufacturer, which will partially offset our cost for having carried these vehicles. 
Despite a very disruptive Takata airbag recall on our business, our industry-leading recall policy is unchanged. Our customers's safety still remains a top priority, and we will not retail any vehicle that has an open recall. 
I'll now turn the call over to our Chief Financial Officer, Cheryl Miller.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike, and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. For the second quarter, we reported net income from continuing operations of $112 million or $1.08 per share versus net income of $115 million or $1 per share during the second quarter of 2015, an
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike, and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. 
For the second quarter, we reported net income from continuing operations of $112 million or $1.08 per share versus net income of $115 million or $1 per share during the second quarter of 2015, an 8% increase on a per-share basis. There were no adjustments to net income in either periods. 
In the second quarter, revenue increased $217 million or 4% compared to the prior year and gross profit improved $23 million or 3%. 
SG&A as a percentage of gross profit was 69.5% for the quarter, which was relatively flat compared to the year ago period. 
We continue to focus on expense discipline and have aligned our cost structure to the plateauing industry environment. 
The provision for income tax in the quarter was $71 million or 38.8%. Net new vehicle floorplan was a benefit of $13.2 million, a decrease of $2.8 million from the second quarter of 2015. The decrease was primarily due to increased floorplan balances and higher interest rates, partially offset by higher floorplan assistance per unit. 
Floorplan debt decreased sequentially, approximately $237 million during the second quarter to $3.8 billion at quarter, primarily due to lower inventory balances, partially offset by increased borrowings on our used vehicle floorplan facilities. 
Nonvehicle interest expense increased to $28.7 million compared to $21.6 million in the second quarter of 2015. The $7.1 million increase in interest expense was driven by higher-average debt balances, resulting primarily from share repurchase and acquisitions. 
At the end of June, we had $2.7 billion of nonvehicle debt, an increase of $28 million compared to March 31, 2016. Nonvehicle debt includes $958 million of outstanding commercial paper borrowings. 
At the end of June, we had no amounts drawn under our revolving credit facility.  As a consequence, our nonvehicle debt fixed the floating mix was approximately 65% fixed and 35% floating. 
During the second quarter, we repurchased 1 million shares for $50 million at an average price of $48.51 per share. AutoNation has approximately $116 million of remaining board authorization for share repurchase. 
As of July 28, there were approximately 102 million shares outstanding and again, this does not include the dilutive impact of stock options. 
Our leverage ratio increased slightly to 2.7x at the end of Q2 as compared to 2.6x at the end of Q1. The leverage ratio was 2.6x on a net debt basis, including used floorplan availability and our covenants limit as a reminder, is 3.75x. 
Capital expenditures were $62 million for the quarter. Capital expenditures are an accrual basis, excluding operating lease buyouts and related asset sales. 
Our quarter end cash balance was $55 million, which combined with our additional borrowing capacity resulted in total liquidity of $853 million at the end of June. 
We remain committed to disciplined expense management, while also opportunistically deploying capital to drive long-term shareholder value. 
Now let me turn you over to our Chief Operating Officer, Bill Berman.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Cheryl, and good morning. Before discussing our results, I'd like to comment on the new vehicle industry selling environment for the quarter. Industry retail sales were down 2%, owned centers were up 13%, and new vehicle leasing penetration, aga
componenttext:
Thanks, Cheryl, and good morning. 
Before discussing our results, I'd like to comment on the new vehicle industry selling environment for the quarter. Industry retail sales were down 2%, owned centers were up 13%, and new vehicle leasing penetration, again, was over 30%. 
Turning to our results, my comments will be on a same-store basis as compared to the prior year unless noted otherwise. Gross profit per variable operations was $442 million, down 5%. Variable growth was $3,376 on a per vehicle retail basis, a decrease of $18 or 1%. New and used same-store unit volume was down 5% compared to the second quarter last year. 
As we stated in the first quarter, we took steps to reduce our inventory level, and we've made progress in the second quarter. We decreased our same-store new unit day supply from 76 days to 70 days or 6,000 units on a sequential basis. 
Our DSO target is in the low to mid-60s, and we expect our inventory level to normalize by the end of the third quarter. 
New vehicle revenue for the quarter was $2.9 billion, a decrease of $49 million or 2%. We retail 79,400 units, a decrease of 5%. New vehicle gross profit was $1,923 on a per vehicle retail basis, down 2%. Manufacturing volume basis in a program with high cell target to continue to create a rational behavior in the marketplace. 
Despite industry retail sales being down in the second quarter, certain manufacturers, in particular, Ford, Chrysler and Nissan, set double-digit lower targets that were unattainable. For reasons these targets were unreasonable, we did not pursue them. 
For the quarter, used vehicle retail revenue was $1 billion, a decrease of $38 million or 3%. Used vehicle retail were 52,300, down 6%. Used vehicle gross profit was $1,548 on a per retail basis, a decrease of $150 or 9%. 
As of June 30, 6,900 units or roughly 20% of our total used vehicle inventory was on hold. 4,300 units or 60% of those units were eligible for manufacture compensation. We anticipate over $3 million of manufacture compensation, which will partially offset our cost. We will recognize this compensation as each of these vehicles are sold. 
Also, at the end of the second quarter, approximately 75% or 5,200 of our used units on hold were related to Takata airbag recall. We started to receive limited Takata airbag replacement parts for certain brands and we expect our used vehicle inventory on hold to peek towards the end of 2016, assuming parts become more readily available and no additional major recalls are issue. 
Customer financial services total gross profit was $211 million, customer financial services gross profit on a per vehicle retail basis was $1,602, an increase of $66 or 4%. 
We set an all-time record in customer care gross profit of $337 million, an increase of $9 million or 3%. 
Also in the quarter, customer care revenue was $773 million, an increase of $17 million or 2%. Customer pay gross was $140 million, up 6% year-over-year. Warranty gross was $68 million, up 9%.  Coalition gross was $30 million, up 1%. 
We're continuing to work on adding additional capacity for our coalition business to meet the higher demand. 
Finally, I'd like to welcome our new Denver, Colorado and Westchester, New York associates to AutoNation, and we'd like to thank AutoNation's 25,000-plus associates for the hard work and dedication. 
I'll now turn the call over to Jon Ferrando, Executive Vice President responsible for M&A.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. In July, we completed the previously announced acquisition of Centennial Chrysler Jeep in Denver, Colorado, a great brand fit for that market. Including this acquisition, we have 17 stores in the Denver marke
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. 
In July, we completed the previously announced acquisition of Centennial Chrysler Jeep in Denver, Colorado, a great brand fit for that market. Including this acquisition, we have 17 stores in the Denver market area. 
Also in July, we completed the previously announced acquisition of 4 Premium Luxury stores in Westchester County, New York. These stores consist of the BMW, Land Rover and Jaguar brands and collectively represent approximately $100 million in annual revenue. 
As part of the acquisition, we will be awarded a Land Rover franchise in White Plains and a Jaguar franchise in Mt. Kisco. 
Once our facility plan is complete, we will have 3 Jaguar and Land Rover stores in new state-of-the-art facilities in Westchester County, 1 in White Plains, 1 in Mt. Kisco and 1 in Larchmont/New Rochelle.  We expect to generate additional $100 million in revenue from these facilities once fully operational. 
We are excited about entering Westchester County, New York, an excellent Premium Luxury market with an outstanding platform of luxury franchises and attractive growth prospects.  The business will be supported by our existing market team based in the Baltimore, Washington, D.C. area and provides an opportunity to further leverage our existing management infrastructure. 
In 2016, we've closed-end on the acquisition of 18 stores, generating $1.1 billion in annual revenue. 
As of today, our store portfolio numbers 373 franchises and 263 stores in 16 states, representing 35 manufacturer brands. 
Looking forward, we will continue to actively pursue acquisitions and new store opportunities with a focus on enhancing brand representation within our existing markets and markets that can be supported by our existing management infrastructure. We will continue to be selective and prudent with our capital with a focus on investing to produce strong returns and long-term shareholder value. 
I will now turn it back to Mike Jackson.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jon. We continue to expect the total industry vehicle sales, including fleet to be above 17 million units. In this current selling environment, we remain committed to managing cost and appropriate inventory levels as well as taking advantage of
componenttext:
Thank you, Jon. We continue to expect the total industry vehicle sales, including fleet to be above 17 million units. In this current selling environment, we remain committed to managing cost and appropriate inventory levels as well as taking advantage of capital allocation opportunities. 
We'd now be delighted to take any of your questions.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Mr. Mike Montani of Evercore ISI.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, I want to ask about, Mike, if you could provide any updates on potential partnership activities with TrueCar following up on the pilot that you all had begun a few months back.
componenttext: First, I want to ask about, Mike, if you could provide any updates on potential partnership activities with TrueCar following up on the pilot that you all had begun a few months back.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike, thank you. I recently met with Chip Perry some time in the last couple of weeks do a review of the pilot that we had kicked off in the middle of the second quarter and benchmark all the results against our hopes and expectations, and it was a c
componenttext: Yes, Mike, thank you. I recently met with Chip Perry some time in the last couple of weeks do a review of the pilot that we had kicked off in the middle of the second quarter and benchmark all the results against our hopes and expectations, and it was a complete success. TrueCar has transformed itself to be really a win-win partner and all the commitments and promises they had made to us were kept 100%. We also discussed the learnings from the pilot and further steps we could make and Chip agreed to go forward with that, and we will expand the pilot during the third quarter, do another review meeting, which I'm very optimistic about. And my expectation now is by the end of the year, TrueCar will have been implemented in all AutoNation stores.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just on a related note maybe, Mike, can you just touch a little bit on the digital initiative with AutoNation Express omnichannel work you guys are doing and also third party lead providers versus internally-sourced leads at this sta
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just on a related note maybe, Mike, can you just touch a little bit on the digital initiative with AutoNation Express omnichannel work you guys are doing and also third party lead providers versus internally-sourced leads at this stage.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, AutoNation Express and the enhancement of the digital capabilities and marketing communication to take traffic to AutoNation branded sites all is doing extremely well. We now generate, I think it's somewhere in the high 20s, our business from AutoNa
componenttext: Well, AutoNation Express and the enhancement of the digital capabilities and marketing communication to take traffic to AutoNation branded sites all is doing extremely well. We now generate, I think it's somewhere in the high 20s, our business from AutoNation sites, so it's really been a complete success. And we have greatly enhanced our Mobile capabilities. So all that's going extremely well. And third parties, we've really achieved our objectives that they are in balance with where we are with our own investment in AutoNation Express, and they are compatible in how they do business in that the AutoNation Express is the best price, that's the price on our site is the best price you can have. It can be the same somewhere else, but it can't be less. And that it has to be about the brand, AutoNation. So compared to where the fork on the road we were at 1.5 years ago, I couldn't be more pleased and delighted with where we are.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. And then just last if I could squeeze one, Mark. In light of Ford's recent towards commentary and I heard some remarks from you earlier on GM, can you just update us, Mike, on what you're hearing from the OEMs in terms of production and how
componenttext: That's great. And then just last if I could squeeze one, Mark. In light of Ford's recent towards commentary and I heard some remarks from you earlier on GM, can you just update us, Mike, on what you're hearing from the OEMs in terms of production and how you guys are thinking strategically moving ahead in terms of balance production versus demand?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if I go back to my keynote speech at the Automative World Congress in early January, I said this mark has plateaued at the auto industry in 3 phases and the most misunderstood and mismanaged space is plateau, running at high 16 million, 17 million un
componenttext: Yes, if I go back to my keynote speech at the Automative World Congress in early January, I said this mark has plateaued at the auto industry in 3 phases and the most misunderstood and mismanaged space is plateau, running at high 16 million, 17 million units. This industry can, if you run it rationally, you can still be quite successful and be profitable. So if I look at how the first half of the year developed well from a market point of view, that's exactly where it is with retail in the second quarter down, let's say, 2% at retail, but it's still considerably higher incentives for that to happen. The recent diversions and manufacturer behavior, I would give -- for instance, I would complement General Motors, and you certainly look at the results, and you see if you find the right balance between supply and demand with a good disciplined approach and really marketing that's focused on the long-term, you can be quite successful. On the margin business, it's going to be very expensive from an incentive point of view. You don't take -- on the other hand, we have other manufacturers who are still very aggressive in their plans and if you want to -- Bill already mentioned it, if you want to look at Ford Motor Company where we have targets for the third quarter that significant number of our stores have targets that are 15%, 20%, 25% up to 40% higher the prior year. Well, it's just not going to happen, that's totally unrealistic, and we're not going to chase it. But it is disruptive in the marketplace and causes irrational behavior and there's a price tags for that. And if you look at Ford's total incentive being up 28% in the second quarter, I don't think they've got a return on that approach. So there's a good contrast as to what I was talking about and how it can be managed differently. Now we'll see what happens from this point. But the headline is progress is being made in principle and maybe we'll make even more progress in the second half of the year.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Pat Archambault with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Pat Archambault with Goldman Sachs.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess, just building on that last point, I'm sure you saw the details of the Ford results, but one of the things that they did is announce a pretty meaningful production cut for the third quarter. And I was just wondering if your commentary is sort
componenttext: Yes, I guess, just building on that last point, I'm sure you saw the details of the Ford results, but one of the things that they did is announce a pretty meaningful production cut for the third quarter. And I was just wondering if your commentary is sort of reflected more of what was going on, up to kind of the end of the second quarter and if there's evidence that the tone has changed because certainly, one would at least given some of the actions one would expect that, that wouldn't have an impact.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Pat, that's a fair point. So the programs that are out there right now that I just referred to may be, you may have in the third quarter a transition quarter where they still have these very aggressive targets to try to clear inventory. But on the ot
componenttext: Yes, Pat, that's a fair point. So the programs that are out there right now that I just referred to may be, you may have in the third quarter a transition quarter where they still have these very aggressive targets to try to clear inventory. But on the other hand, they're cutting production so as to be in a better place in the fourth quarter. That could be. I still think where you take a significant percentage of your retail muscle and put it on the sidelines by putting out unrealistic targets is not the best way to get there. So your point is very fair. We could be in a better place 3 months from now.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just on the stop sale inventory, I guess, you said that it would peak towards the end of the year and I guess, just so to better understand why that is because have they -- are they still in the process of identifying the numbers that you'll
componenttext: Got it. And just on the stop sale inventory, I guess, you said that it would peak towards the end of the year and I guess, just so to better understand why that is because have they -- are they still in the process of identifying the numbers that you'll  have all of those so that's why you're repairing some but your kind of identifying more inventory faster? Is that kind of the way it's working?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pat, that's very insightful, again. Exactly what's happening. So the good news first is that devices are beginning to arrive, and we're at a point where certain manufacturers where we can batch order devices and not go VIN by VIN. And we'll begin to repai
componenttext: Pat, that's very insightful, again. Exactly what's happening. So the good news first is that devices are beginning to arrive, and we're at a point where certain manufacturers where we can batch order devices and not go VIN by VIN. And we'll begin to repair those vehicles, we'll begin to sell this vehicles and we'll begin to recognize the compensation that is due on those vehicles in a manufacturer. So that's a good news. That would tend to say the worst is over. On the other hand, in the second quarter, they announced another, I don't know, 10 million, 20 million of Takata airbag recall, which we don't have the VIN numbers yet but those VIN numbers will come in the second half of the year and those parts will not come until the first half of next year because there, on the pasture side, and they got to go through a whole design certification process to get the replacement parts to it. So it's a little difficult and a little risky to say we're out of the woods yet on Takata if I look at the moving factors. So that's why we have good news, but I have the responsibility to tell you we still got a lot of VIN numbers that we are due. That [indiscernible] there are not parts.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mike. Rick, we continue to see good opportunity out in the marketplace. I think the Auto stock sector revaluation is working its way through. We have a number of conversations ongoing. That being said, given our position, we do get a look at a lot o
componenttext: Sure, Mike. Rick, we continue to see good opportunity out in the marketplace. I think the Auto stock sector revaluation is working its way through. We have a number of conversations ongoing. That being said, given our position, we do get a look at a lot of opportunities and pass on the vast majority. We can be very selective in what we do, and you'll see us continuing to operate that way and looking for great brands, good cultural fit, excellent locations and markets where we have management infrastructure, so we are pleased with what we've done year-to-date and I think over the next few years, there will be a lot of opportunities that we'll be able to take advantage of.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Also interested your strategy to not chase some of these volume-based incentives. What about the risks there in terms of allocations and the implications for market share and may be acquisition approvals?
componenttext: Also interested your strategy to not chase some of these volume-based incentives. What about the risks there in terms of allocations and the implications for market share and may be acquisition approvals?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Mike Jackson. Yes, it I think it is a major source of irritation and friction between retailers and manufacturers. In one way, it's not a difficult decision because the targets are so irrational or so unreasonable that you have no choice but to pu
componenttext: This is Mike Jackson. Yes, it I think it is a major source of irritation and friction between retailers and manufacturers. In one way, it's not a difficult decision because the targets are so irrational or so unreasonable that you have no choice but to pull back volume and try to manage for growth. The [indiscernible] and how arbitrary the targets are is the problem because you have neighboring stores of competitors got completely different targets that's very reachable and therefore, they're on a different price basis and then you have others who think they can just make it that when they close, they're not going to make it, they did extremely irrational things. So it really difficult situation to manage. But you're right, it will be a source of friction. But the extreme practitioners of volume-based incentives are really, at this point, Nissan, Chrysler and Ford, I would say the intensity of the discussion between dealers, retailers, and those companies is going up. Some are even questioning the legality of how those programs are run in the fairness of those programs. So it's -- I think we're approaching a moment where I would hope that these extreme fair steps, which, again, I called out in my keynote speech in January, would be the issue in 2016 because if you take away a growing marketplace and these stair steps really don't work because they're entirely based on growth. Hopefully, the industry over the second half of the year will come to a better place on understanding how these programs can work and can't work. But at the moment, it's a source of real friction.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think some of your peers also backing away from chasing those incentives?
componenttext: And I think some of your peers also backing away from chasing those incentives?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, just because of where the calendar I would observe everybody else has reported. And I see certain similarities. So all the public traded groups are behaving in a very rational way. They will all say, hey, this markets plateaued, we need to bring --
componenttext: Well, just because of where the calendar I would observe everybody else has reported. And I see certain similarities. So all the public traded groups are behaving in a very rational way. They will all say, hey, this markets plateaued, we need to bring -- we need to adjust costs, and we need to bring inventories into life. I think it's very beneficial to the industry to see that big companies behaving in a rational way. And then to call out why if you look at Group 1, they did a fantastic job of saying, you know what, these targets are irrational, not attainable, we're going to manage for gross because we can't get the volume numbers and they actually increase their new vehicle front end gross and gave up the volume. So finding that line is difficult and ongoing, but it is a point of contention. I don't, in principle, have a problem with volume targets because they're realistic and attainable. But when you put out -- when you misjudge the market, and you put out the target that's not attainable and you'd sprinkle it out there in a capricious involuntary way, it's really disruptive in the marketplace and very difficult to manage, and you're going to have a lot of controversy with dealers. Yet you can go out to find dealers who say, they like you. Well, I can tell you something, they got a easy target there. They get an easy target, you'll love it. And for all those -- and since we have such a big footprint in so many stores, we see that without line of reason, you end up with stores that get huge targets, plus 25%, we have other stores that got lower targets than prior year. Go figure. So that's about much color that I can give you.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Paresh Jain from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Paresh Jain from Morgan Stanley.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, you talked about the industry plateauing at a higher level now, but in a scenario, where saw declines, 10% to 15%, do you see yourself getting more aggressive at acquisitions or wait for signs of another up to of such a decline?
componenttext: Mike, you talked about the industry plateauing at a higher level now, but in a scenario, where saw declines, 10% to 15%, do you see yourself getting more aggressive at acquisitions or wait for signs of another up to of such a decline?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think a decline of 10% to 15% in auto sales would require a significant recession and a significant increase in interest rates above normal, so let's do interest rates first. They are so far from even being normal, let alone above normal. We're not g
componenttext: So I think a decline of 10% to 15% in auto sales would require a significant recession and a significant increase in interest rates above normal, so let's do interest rates first. They are so far from even being normal, let alone above normal. We're not going to have a decline in sales because there's been some traumatic significant increase in interest rates. I think we're looking at an environment where we have very low little or reasonable interest rates and very low and reasonable gas prices, thereby, keeping the mix [indiscernible] for years. Now and something else happened in the world that hammers the U.S. with recession? I suppose that can happen, but I don't see that significant recession that would decline sale by 10% to 15%. So my outlook is high industry sale, high 16 million, just over 17 million for the next several years.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. So then a broader question of the future of parts and services business here, which is more defensible, of course. Obviously, there's this rise of active safety and over the  year update, which is a potential headwind for this business. But ar
componenttext: Understood. So then a broader question of the future of parts and services business here, which is more defensible, of course. Obviously, there's this rise of active safety and over the  year update, which is a potential headwind for this business. But are there any other offsets to it? Like are there new revenue streams dealers can capture especially related to fleet management?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the -- if you look at the safety devices that are coming around metonymy, and we are all for them, but if you really look at their realistic ability to become a significant percentage of the 250 million vehicles that are out there operating
componenttext: Well, I think the -- if you look at the safety devices that are coming around metonymy, and we are all for them, but if you really look at their realistic ability to become a significant percentage of the 250 million vehicles that are out there operating on the road and how long it takes to turn over, it's a very, very gradual process. At the same time, the cost of these systems and devices in vehicles is going up exponentially and the expertise to be able to deal with it is consolidating into fewer and fewer hands. So I think they offset each other for the next decade plus, and then ask me in 10 years for an update. I think we can really grow our customer care, including collision.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mr. John Murphy of Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mr. John Murphy of Bank of America.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, maybe just to stay on the parts and service for the first question I mean, 2.2% on same-store sales base was a little bit on the light side, but it sounds like your customer and warranty were up, I think, 6% to 9%, respectively, and the slight weakn
componenttext: Mike, maybe just to stay on the parts and service for the first question I mean, 2.2% on same-store sales base was a little bit on the light side, but it sounds like your customer and warranty were up, I think, 6% to 9%, respectively, and the slight weakness came in collision, which is up only 1%. And the way you discussed it, it sounded like you're alluding to some sort of capacity constraints there, and you need to maybe add capacity for collision. So just curious what the story is there and what you have in the plans to really increase capacity there.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now the good news, and Bill will give you the exact figures in a second, is that our customer pay business is up exactly where we wanted to be, solid mid-single digits. And what really has slowed is our internal business. Now here's the way to take about
componenttext: Now the good news, and Bill will give you the exact figures in a second, is that our customer pay business is up exactly where we wanted to be, solid mid-single digits. And what really has slowed is our internal business. Now here's the way to take about internal. That's volume related to our new and used business so as we have these backlog of vehicles on hold, we are not repairing them until they get the parts from the manufacturer for the recall so that we can do the vehicle all in one time, make it frontline ready and then sell it. And on time sale, we'll recognize that all internal work that we did. So that has impacted our internal number. And Bill, why don't you talk about what internal was in the second quarter and talk about our hopes to add capacity on collision.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks, Mike. John, so like you said, we're up 6% in our CP, which is strong and steady performance. We will continue to see that kind of growth available in the future. Warranty was up 9%, but to Mike's point, we still have some pent-up demand ther
componenttext: Okay, thanks, Mike. John, so like you said, we're up 6% in our CP, which is strong and steady performance. We will continue to see that kind of growth available in the future. Warranty was up 9%, but to Mike's point, we still have some pent-up demand there with cars that we have on hold that are waiting warranty repairs from Takata air bags. On collision, you called that out right. We have record production levels, and we definitely have capacity issues. Not necessarily with people, it's more of a facility. And then on the internal piece quarter-over-quarter, year-over-year, we're down about 5%. But to Mike's point, that's 100% related to the number of new cars coming into inventory and the number of used cars that we're able to put through our system and put in the frontline. So less cars on recall hold, we'll be able to see here an increase our internal gross.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And John, we will add capacity on the coalition side. We like that business, as I said, when an accident happens, there's a lot more work to do.
componenttext: And John, we will add capacity on the coalition side. We like that business, as I said, when an accident happens, there's a lot more work to do.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: How fast can that capacity be added? Is that kind of a thing that's a couple of months, or is that 1 year or 2?
componenttext: How fast can that capacity be added? Is that kind of a thing that's a couple of months, or is that 1 year or 2?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it takes quite some time, but it's already underway. So Bill, when would you say the capacity comes online that we'll be able to be reflected in our numbers?
componenttext: Well, it takes quite some time, but it's already underway. So Bill, when would you say the capacity comes online that we'll be able to be reflected in our numbers?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll see a little bit of increase in capacity in the third quarter and then it will ramp up significantly in the fourth quarter through all of 2017.
componenttext: We'll see a little bit of increase in capacity in the third quarter and then it will ramp up significantly in the fourth quarter through all of 2017.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, that's incredibly helpful. And just also follow up on the stop sale. I mean, I understand there's something a little bit of a surge in parts and service, on the warranty side and used vehicle sales that are kind of clear here. Just curious when you
componenttext: Great, that's incredibly helpful. And just also follow up on the stop sale. I mean, I understand there's something a little bit of a surge in parts and service, on the warranty side and used vehicle sales that are kind of clear here. Just curious when you think that will happen. It sounds like probably first half of next year. And really in the interim, how much of a wait is that on results? I mean, is it really just the cost of carry of inventory that you won't get reimbursed for until you sell them or just really what's kind of if you quantify or just give us some kind of magnitude of the wait that, that's creating on results.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The [indiscernible] John, is significantly, really, where you put all these cars and we've had to go out and rent storage lots and but it's still is disruptive to frontline ready inventory to go. I think for the vehicles that we have right this moment, ri
componenttext: The [indiscernible] John, is significantly, really, where you put all these cars and we've had to go out and rent storage lots and but it's still is disruptive to frontline ready inventory to go. I think for the vehicles that we have right this moment, right this moment, I think the majority of the parts will come between now and year-end, and we'll be able to sell -- we'll be able to retail them, recognize the compensation we do, we'll do and move internal work and recognize that also. However, for these additional Takata air bags announced in the first half of 2016, there are no parts, and we will begin to get the VIN numbers very soon, which means, we're going to repeat this whole movie over, again, for this next wave, and that wave is going is to take us into 2017 before we get parts. Bill, anything you'd like to add there? Anything I?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, I think you've said it perfectly. We'll be able to clear out our existing inventory on Q3 and Q4. The real unknown is how extent the recalls in the future will be. There's more Takata air bags that will hit the recall over the coming months, but we
componenttext: Mike, I think you've said it perfectly. We'll be able to clear out our existing inventory on Q3 and Q4. The real unknown is how extent the recalls in the future will be. There's more Takata air bags that will hit the recall over the coming months, but we have a plan and a process to deal with it, and we're executing upon it at the high level.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just lastly, Mike, you alluded to, and we've seen this data where leasing has been surging as a percent of sales, and it looks like in the first half of the year, it was north of 30%, which is well above normal levels of 20%. Just curious h
componenttext: Okay. And then just lastly, Mike, you alluded to, and we've seen this data where leasing has been surging as a percent of sales, and it looks like in the first half of the year, it was north of 30%, which is well above normal levels of 20%. Just curious how that's impacting sales and profit here in the near term and if you see that creating any disruption or how you might deal with it as we see this very large wave of vehicles coming back off lease in '18, '19 and '20?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's one of the distortions that I'm concerned about. So when I look at from the manufacturer, I really think they shouldn't break into double-digit as a percent of their average MSRP, I think you hit a wall of diminishing return where the
componenttext: Yes, I think that's one of the distortions that I'm concerned about. So when I look at from the manufacturer, I really think they shouldn't break into double-digit as a percent of their average MSRP, I think you hit a wall of diminishing return where the incentive is now such a level that it's already depressing the resell value so you haven't really delivered -- reduce the net difference in the cost of the vehicle. Does that make sense? Where your next dollar of incentive doesn't have a 10%, doesn't have the same impact that you went from 5% to 6%. There is a point of diminishing return that's dramatic. Second, I agree with you. Leasing is the same thing, it's -- you're selling a seat of day of reckoning that you really don't want, namely that you have so many vehicles coming back that are based on the residual value that's going to be higher than what the marketplace can handle. Now that -- all those risk are at the OEM level, not at the retail level, but we all know if you're basically pulling business forward now, that means that when the day of reckoning comes to the disruption is great. And I'd just rather see the business managed more rationally and with stability now so that despite period is more sustainable. That's what I'm advocating.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Absolutely, Mike. So we're seeing strong growth in Florida, especially in the Southern part the state. California is also improving and continuing to grow. Texas places and Colorado energy market are facing extreme headwinds. Operationally, we've been able to seek here and adjust our business model and cost structures to be able to combat that the best of our ability, but as you see today, oil in the $40 to $42 a barrel, it definitely poses some headwinds for the Southern part of Texas.

componenttextpreview: Okay, it's significant.
componenttext: Okay, it's significant.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And a question on collision, as you expand that business, is that something which you get involved in the direct repair programs of the insurance companies and really drive outside volume to that business, sort of like the caliber service things ar
componenttext: Great. And a question on collision, as you expand that business, is that something which you get involved in the direct repair programs of the insurance companies and really drive outside volume to that business, sort of like the caliber service things are doing? Or do you really sort of keep that as a more in-house boutique business?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we [indiscernible] describe it the first time. Again, it's part of our investment in the brand AutoNation why we did it, so we've extended the brand into our customer care products and protection products and have had amazing acceptance satisfaction a
componenttext: No, we [indiscernible] describe it the first time. Again, it's part of our investment in the brand AutoNation why we did it, so we've extended the brand into our customer care products and protection products and have had amazing acceptance satisfaction and improved results for us for that move. And we intend to extend the AutoNation brand to the collision business. All of our collision centers will be branded AutoNation and the once we expand will be branded AutoNation. And so brand extension -- so one of the reasons we made a significant effort into the AutoNation brand and digital is for brand extension. So the heavy lifting [indiscernible] one in a sense that the risk and the investment that it took to establish the brand AutoNation has accomplished, the risk and the cost to build the digital muscle has been accomplished and the obvious benefit existing business is there, that's fine. But the brand extension and possibility that exists from having those 2 pillars are what we intend to realize over the next several years.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask and I know, Mike, you've alluded to this in your prepared remarks various times in the Q&A. But just sort of wanted to be very clear because it's a concern that's been voiced I think numerous times over the course of the last few months at
componenttext: I wanted to ask and I know, Mike, you've alluded to this in your prepared remarks various times in the Q&A. But just sort of wanted to be very clear because it's a concern that's been voiced I think numerous times over the course of the last few months at least to us I the investor conversations. Do you believe that SAAR having grown to the point, which is record last year, has effectively pulled forward demand from the used vehicle market. And if not, where do you think or what indications are you seeing to give you confidence that when supply does ramp, there will be demand for those used vehicles?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think I've been very outspoken that, and you're exactly on point that this is one of the reasons why I see on my stance at the beginning of the year was so important because ultimately, and a sort of alluded to it earlier, it's the OEMs over to it an
componenttext: So I think I've been very outspoken that, and you're exactly on point that this is one of the reasons why I see on my stance at the beginning of the year was so important because ultimately, and a sort of alluded to it earlier, it's the OEMs over to it and pushed incentives too, overproduced pushed leasing so far. You are absolutely taking customers from the used vehicle market and converting them to the new vehicle market and at the same time, you're  increasing the supply of used vehicle coming back to the market on a faster term. Well, you can see that, that is unsustainable, and it will be a day of reckoning. So I've been very clear that there is a risk there. I don't think we've gone over the cliff yet, I think it's still -- there's still plenty of time to manage this rationally and discipline. And don't forget the retail market for used vehicles is 40 million units. So if you put it all together, we're looking at a market that's 55 million to 60 million units between new and used. It's very manageable. But can you screw it up? Yes, you can. And that's why we're speaking up. And by the way, I have to say if I look at all the other publicly traded groups that have reported, they have all talked about taking a disciplined approach on the cost side and on the inventory side. I haven't checked everybody's numbers, but I have the sense that everybody's days supply has come down sequentially during the second quarter so everybody said they would do it in their out there doing that, and that's a very strong single back to the manufacturers, which they don't like, but I think is healthy that we can have a very profitable, sustainable, rational plateau period until we have very high interest rates for major recession, and then volumes will flow. Is that helpful?
