componenttextpreview: Yes, I think you said it right, Mike. It's a day-to-day fight. We reduced our day supply by 6 days from the end of Q1 2 to the end of Q2, we'll be to our target area by the mid-60s by the end of Q3. But it is a store by store, model by model, brand by bra
componenttext: Yes, I think you said it right, Mike. It's a day-to-day fight. We reduced our day supply by 6 days from the end of Q1 2 to the end of Q2, we'll be to our target area by the mid-60s by the end of Q3. But it is a store by store, model by model, brand by brand fight. We're down 6,000 units sequentially, and we're going to continue to get that down. But there's a tremendous amount of pressure coming from the OEMs to accept unneeded and unwanted inventory.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And by the way, just to make an observation, I ignore the days supply numbers in automotive news because they include fleet sales and the selling rate, which is ridiculous. It should be -- tell me what retail sales were versus retail inventory, that's the
componenttext: And by the way, just to make an observation, I ignore the days supply numbers in automotive news because they include fleet sales and the selling rate, which is ridiculous. It should be -- tell me what retail sales were versus retail inventory, that's the real world on what's going on with day supply. To add in a fleet sale into the selling rate to divide into retail inventory gives you an unrecognizable number as to what's happening in the real world in my humble opinion.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, absolutely. On opposed to philosophical side, I mean, what is the rationale behind the irrational behavior by some of these OEMs? I mean,, industry can't grow at an 18 million, 19 million, 20 million maybe it could, but it doesn't seem that wa
componenttext: Absolutely, absolutely. On opposed to philosophical side, I mean, what is the rationale behind the irrational behavior by some of these OEMs? I mean,, industry can't grow at an 18 million, 19 million, 20 million maybe it could, but it doesn't seem that way. And you cited several OEMs that are a rationale. Do you have any examples of OEMs that are more rational in this environment currently?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, sure. I mean, I already called out General Motors. Honda has always been very rational discipline, same with Toyota. By and large, the Germans has been -- they have a little diversions from their usual discipline with the carrying far too much invento
componenttext: Oh, sure. I mean, I already called out General Motors. Honda has always been very rational discipline, same with Toyota. By and large, the Germans has been -- they have a little diversions from their usual discipline with the carrying far too much inventory into 2016, which we're still trying to work our way through but, that's sort of like an aberration and I'm optimistic and hopeful that would come into line. And as far as the what the issue is, there's agreement -- seems to be agreement on within the industry now on plateau. But then I get the speech for the next 20 minutes as to why their company is going to be different. And not everybody can walk on water. So that's an issue. And as far as the pressure, I can tell you has having been at the table, you still have relatively high fixed cost or some cost where the marginal cost to produce another unit, the pressure is absolutely there, and they recognize revenue on shipment to us, thanks to us as Thanksgiving turkey, they recognize their revenue and there it is, that the third real for the industry and why this is a struggle. But hey, we're speaking up and I think we're making progress, we're not where we need to be, but I'm hopeful we're making progress.

componenttext: Our classic answer that just look at our 15-year of track record, we look at where our stock is trading and if it's attractive, we move aggressively. Existing business comes first on capital, we're invested in our stores, invested in our brand, we've invested in our digital capability, that's first call and then we look at the balance between what we can buy the stock at and acquisitions. Certainly, the stock is extremely attractive in the first quarter, and we bought a lot.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've taken a close look at millennials for the last 5 years, a tremendous -- we have a tremendous insight into it. All of our capabilities that we've talked about a big part of that was the millennial generation and designing it in a way that will appeal
componenttext: We've taken a close look at millennials for the last 5 years, a tremendous -- we have a tremendous insight into it. All of our capabilities that we've talked about a big part of that was the millennial generation and designing it in a way that will appeal to millennial generations, and we have more updates in the pipeline that will even make it more effective. My view is that millennials will buy cars. I think I have to check, but I think they have bought more cars than any other generation. The millennials came of age with a great recession, they went back to school and double down in education and student debt. They are now entering the workforce, they have to pay down that student debt, but their fundamental desires to marry, have children, have a home, have a car are there. You have to do business with them differently, you have communicate with them differently, you have to know how to market with them differently, but those drivers are there. That's in principle of what we believe.

componenttext: Just maybe one quick one where you've been talking about the divergence in behavior amongst OEMs. Mike, just wondering how you kind of see where the balance starts to tip one way or another, how many OEMs behaving like Ford, Fiat and Nissan does it take to kind of upset the apple cart and when do we sort become the front in the slowly boiling water here?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say freeze enough, and so I think we're at a crucial point because if I look at the whole history, Chrysler was the first practitioner of the aggressive stair steps. They were highly skilled, very professional and rational, and they probably
componenttext:
Yes, I would say freeze enough, and so I think we're at a crucial point because if I look at the whole history, Chrysler was the first practitioner of the aggressive stair steps. They were highly skilled, very professional and rational, and they probably today are the most skilled practitioner of aggressive stair steps. Then you had Nissan arrived, which is just a little loose cannon rolling back and forth across the deck, wreaking havoc. And now you've had Ford as of this year, join in. So if more go down that road, that is a real problem. But I think it's going to go the other way. The price tag of irrational stair steps incentives is beginning to be understood and the damage to the brand, the change in your customer base, the impact on customer loyalty, the dissatisfaction and the fairness of pricing due to the fact that you've introduced a casino 3 car monte system, you've unleashed that on your customers, the manufacturer cannot talk about customer satisfaction in one breadth and say, on the other hand, going to do aggressive stairsteps because it's basically massively unfair to the customers. And finally, the relationship with your retailers that you really just wreak havoc. So I think the long-term yes, it's like heroine, it feels nice, it feels pretty good, but then you look in the mirror one day, and you look like [indiscernible], and you realize you can't go on like this. So we're at a crucial point, could go either way, I'm saying it's hopefully going to go back more towards irrational. But that's reason enough. 
Right thank you, everyone, for joining us today. We very much appreciate your questions. We appreciate your time. All the best.

Now we'll turn the call over to Andrew Wamser, Treasurer and Vice President of Finance for AutoNation. Sir, you may begin.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to AutoNation's Second Quarter 2016 Conference Call and Webcast. Leading our call today will be Mike Jackson, our Chairman, CEO and President; Cheryl Miller, our Chief Financial Officer; Bill
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to AutoNation's Second Quarter 2016 Conference Call and Webcast. 
Leading our call today will be Mike Jackson, our Chairman, CEO and President; Cheryl Miller, our Chief Financial Officer; Bill Berman, our Chief Operating Officer; and Jon Ferrando, our EVP responsible for M&A. Following their remarks, we will open up the call for questions. Robert Quartaro and I will also be available by phone following the call to address any additional questions that you may have. 
Before we begin, let me read our brief statement regarding forward-looking comments. Certain statements and information on this call will constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Federal Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Such forward-looking statements involve risks, which may cause actual results or performance to differ materially from such forward-looking statements. Additional discussions of factors that could cause actual results to differ materially are contained in our press release issued earlier today and our SEC filings, including our most recent annual report on Form 10-K and subsequent quarterly reports on Form 10-Q and in current reports on Form 8-K. Certain non-GAAP financial measures as defined under SEC rules will be discussed on this call. Reconciliations are provided in our press release and on our website located at investors.autonation.com. 
And now I'll turn the call over to AutoNation's Chairman, CEO and President, Mike Jackson.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Today, we reported an all-time record earnings per share from continuing operations of $1.08, an 8% increase as compared to EPS from continuing operations of $1 for the same period in the prior year. We achieved
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Today, we reported an all-time record earnings per share from continuing operations of $1.08, an 8% increase as compared to EPS from continuing operations of $1 for the same period in the prior year. We achieved record EPS from continuing operations as we began to see the results of adjusting our cost structure and inventory levels to a plateauing industry sales environment. We also saw a benefit from our opportunistic capital allocation strategy, which included acquisitions and share repurchase. 
Revenue for the quarter totaled $5.4 billion compared to $5.2 billion in the same period a year ago, an increase of 4%. AutoNation's total retail new vehicle unit sales for the quarter were flat. In a same-store basis, retail new vehicle unit sales were down 5%. 
During the quarter, we continue to see disruption from the Takata airbag recall, which impacted our used vehicle business. Approximately 20% of our used vehicle inventory is currently on hold due to open recalls and approximately 75% of those vehicles are related to Takata airbags. 
Second quarter was a transitional quarter for certain brands as replacement parts for the Takata airbags became available. We anticipate that our used vehicle inventory on hold will peak towards the end of 2016. 
Also in the second half of the year, once the vehicles that have been on hold are repaired and sold, we will recognize compensation related to certain brands paid by the manufacturer, which will partially offset our cost for having carried these vehicles. 
Despite a very disruptive Takata airbag recall on our business, our industry-leading recall policy is unchanged. Our customers' safety still remains a top priority, and we will not retail any vehicle that has an open recall. 
I'll now turn the call over to our Chief Financial Officer, Cheryl Miller.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike, and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. For the second quarter, we reported net income from continuing operations of $112 million or $1.08 per share versus net income of $115 million or $1 per share during the second quarter of 2015, an
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike, and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. 
For the second quarter, we reported net income from continuing operations of $112 million or $1.08 per share versus net income of $115 million or $1 per share during the second quarter of 2015, an 8% increase on a per share basis. There were no adjustments to net income in either period. 
In the second quarter, revenue increased $217 million or 4% compared to the prior year and gross profit improved $23 million or 3%. 
SG&A as a percentage of gross profit was 69.5% for the quarter, which was relatively flat compared to the year ago period. 
We continue to focus on expense discipline and have aligned our cost structure to the plateauing industry environment. 
The provision for income tax in the quarter was $71 million or 38.8%. Net new vehicle floorplan was a benefit of $13.2 million, a decrease of $2.8 million from the second quarter of 2015. The decrease was primarily due to increased floorplan balances and higher interest rates, partially offset by higher floorplan assistance per unit. 
Floorplan debt decreased sequentially, approximately $237 million during the second quarter to $3.8 billion at quarter end, primarily due to lower inventory balances, partially offset by increased borrowings on our used vehicle floorplan facilities. 
Nonvehicle interest expense increased to $28.7 million compared to $21.6 million in the second quarter of 2015. The $7.1 million increase in interest expense was driven by higher average debt balances, resulting primarily from share repurchase and acquisitions. 
At the end of June, we had $2.7 billion of nonvehicle debt, an increase of $28 million compared to March 31, 2016. Nonvehicle debt includes $958 million of outstanding commercial paper borrowings. 
At the end of June, we had no amounts drawn under our revolving credit facility. As a consequence, our nonvehicle debt fixed to floating mix was approximately 65% fixed and 35% floating. 
During the second quarter, we repurchased 1 million shares for $50 million at an average price of $48.51 per share. AutoNation has approximately $116 million of remaining board authorization for share repurchase. 
As of July 28, there were approximately 102 million shares outstanding and again, this does not include the dilutive impact of stock options. 
Our leverage ratio increased slightly to 2.7x at the end of Q2 as compared to 2.6x at the end of Q1. The leverage ratio was 2.6x on a net debt basis, including used floorplan availability, and our covenant limit, as a reminder, is 3.75x. 
Capital expenditures were $62 million for the quarter. Capital expenditures are on an accrual basis, excluding operating lease buyouts and related asset sales. 
Our quarter-end cash balance was $55 million, which combined with our additional borrowing capacity resulted in total liquidity of $853 million at the end of June. 
We remain committed to disciplined expense management, while also opportunistically deploying capital to drive long-term shareholder value. 
Now let me turn you over to our Chief Operating Officer, Bill Berman.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Cheryl, and good morning. Before discussing our results, I'd like to comment on the new vehicle industry selling environment for the quarter. Industry retail sales were down 2%, owned centers were up 13% and new vehicle leasing penetration, again,
componenttext:
Thanks, Cheryl, and good morning. Before discussing our results, I'd like to comment on the new vehicle industry selling environment for the quarter. Industry retail sales were down 2%, owned centers were up 13% and new vehicle leasing penetration, again, was over 30%. 
Turning to our results, my comments will be on a same-store basis as compared to the prior year unless noted otherwise. Gross profit per variable operations was $442 million, down 5%. Variable gross was $3,376 on a per vehicle retail basis, a decrease of $18 or 1%. New and used same-store unit volume was down 5% compared to the second quarter last year. 
As we stated in the first quarter, we took steps to reduce our inventory levels, and we've made progress in the second quarter. We decreased our same-store new unit day supply from 76 days to 70 days or 6,000 units on a sequential basis. 
Our DSO target is in the low to mid-60s, and we expect our inventory levels to normalize by the end of the third quarter. 
New vehicle revenue for the quarter was $2.9 billion, a decrease of $49 million or 2%. We retail 79,400 units, a decrease of 5%. New vehicle gross profit was $1,923 on a per vehicle retail basis, down 2%. Manufactured volume basis in our program with high-cell target should continue to create a rational behavior in the marketplace. 
Despite industry retail sales being down in the second quarter, certain manufacturers, in particular, Ford, Chrysler and Nissan, set double-digit lower targets that were unattainable. For retail, these targets were unreasonable, we did not pursue them. 
For the quarter, used vehicle retail revenue was $1 billion, a decrease of $38 million or 3%. Used vehicle retail were 52,300, down 6%. Used vehicle gross profit was $1,548 on a per-retail basis, a decrease of $150 or 9%. As of June 30, 6,900 units or roughly 20% of our total used vehicle inventory was on hold, 4,300 units or 60% of those units were eligible for manufacture compensation. We anticipate over $3 million of manufacture compensation, which will partially offset our cost. We will recognize this compensation as each of these vehicles are sold. 
Also, at the end of the second quarter, approximately 75% or 5,200 of our used units on hold were related to Takata airbag recall. We started to receive limited Takata airbag replacement parts for certain brands, and we expect our used vehicle inventory on hold to peek towards the end of 2016, assuming parts become more readily available and no additional major recalls are issued. 
Customer financial services total gross profit was $211 million. Customer financial services gross profit on a per vehicle retail basis was $1,602, an increase of $66 or 4%. We set an all-time record in customer care gross profit of $337 million, an increase of $9 million or 3%. 
Also in the quarter, customer care revenue was $773 million, an increase of $17 million or 2%. Customer pay gross was $140 million, up 6% year-over-year. Warranty gross was $68 million, up 9%. Collision gross was $30 million, up 1%. We're continuing to work on adding additional capacity for our Collision business to meet the higher demand. 
Finally, I'd like to welcome our new Denver, Colorado and Westchester, New York associates to AutoNation, and we'd like to thank AutoNation's 25,000-plus associates for the hard work and dedication. 
I'll now turn the call over to Jon Ferrando, Executive Vice President responsible for M&A.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. In July, we completed the previously announced acquisition of Centennial Chrysler Jeep in Denver, Colorado, a great brand fit for that market. Including this acquisition, we have 17 stores in the Denver market
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. In July, we completed the previously announced acquisition of Centennial Chrysler Jeep in Denver, Colorado, a great brand fit for that market. Including this acquisition, we have 17 stores in the Denver market area. 
Also in July, we completed the previously announced acquisition of 4 Premium Luxury stores in Westchester County, New York. These stores consist of the BMW, Land Rover and Jaguar brands and collectively represent approximately $100 million in annual revenue. 
As part of the acquisition, we will be awarded a Land Rover franchise in White Plains and a Jaguar franchise in Mt. Kisco. 
Once our facility plan is complete, we will have 3 Jaguar and Land Rover stores in new state-of-the-art facilities in Westchester County, 1 in White Plains, 1 in Mt. Kisco and 1 in Larchmont/New Rochelle. We expect to generate an additional $100 million in revenue from these facilities once fully operational. 
We are excited about entering Westchester County, New York, an excellent Premium Luxury market with an outstanding platform of luxury franchises and attractive growth prospects. The business will be supported by our existing market team based in the Baltimore, Washington, D.C. area and provides an opportunity to further leverage our existing management infrastructure. 
In 2016, we've closed on the acquisition of 18 stores, generating $1.1 billion in annual revenue. 
As of today, our store portfolio numbers 373 franchises and 263 stores in 16 states, representing 35 manufacturer brands. 
Looking forward, we will continue to actively pursue acquisitions and new store opportunities with a focus on enhancing brand representation within our existing markets and markets that can be supported by our existing management infrastructure. We will continue to be selective and prudent with our capital with a focus on investing to produce strong returns and long-term shareholder value. 
I will now turn it back to Mike Jackson.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jon. We continue to expect the total industry vehicle sales, including fleet to be above 17 million units. In this current selling environment, we remain committed to managing cost and appropriate inventory levels as well as take advantage of c
componenttext:
Thank you, Jon. We continue to expect the total industry vehicle sales, including fleet to be above 17 million units. In this current selling environment, we remain committed to managing cost and appropriate inventory levels as well as take advantage of capital allocation opportunities. 
We'll now be delighted to take any of your questions.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Mr. Mike Montani of Evercore ISI.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Mr. Mike Montani of Evercore ISI.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, I want to ask about, Mike, if you could provide any updates on potential partnership activities with TrueCar following up on the pilot that you all had begun a few months back.
componenttext: First, I want to ask about, Mike, if you could provide any updates on potential partnership activities with TrueCar following up on the pilot that you all had begun a few months back.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike, thank you. I recently met with Chip Perry sometime in the last couple of weeks to do a review on the pilot that we had kicked off in the middle of the second quarter and benchmark all the results against our hopes and expectations, and it was a
componenttext: Yes, Mike, thank you. I recently met with Chip Perry sometime in the last couple of weeks to do a review on the pilot that we had kicked off in the middle of the second quarter and benchmark all the results against our hopes and expectations, and it was a complete success. TrueCar has transformed itself into being really a win-win partner and all the commitments and promises they had made to us were kept 100%. We also discussed the learnings from the pilot and further steps we could make, and Chip agreed to go forward with that. And we will expand the pilot during the third quarter, do another review meeting, which I'm very optimistic about. And my expectation now is, by the end of the year, TrueCar will have been implemented in all AutoNation stores.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And I guess on a related note, maybe, Mike, can you just touch a little bit on the digital initiative with AutoNation Express omnichannel selling work you guys are doing and also third-party lead providers versus internally sourced leads at t
componenttext: Okay, great. And I guess on a related note, maybe, Mike, can you just touch a little bit on the digital initiative with AutoNation Express omnichannel selling work you guys are doing and also third-party lead providers versus internally sourced leads at this stage.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, AutoNation Express and the enhancement of the digital capabilities and marketing communication to take traffic to AutoNation-branded sites all is going extremely well. We now generate, I think, it's somewhere in the high 20s, our business from AutoN
componenttext: Well, AutoNation Express and the enhancement of the digital capabilities and marketing communication to take traffic to AutoNation-branded sites all is going extremely well. We now generate, I think, it's somewhere in the high 20s, our business from AutoNation sites. So it's really been a complete success. And we have greatly enhanced our Mobile capabilities. So all of that's going extremely well. And third parties, we've really achieved our objectives that they are in balance with where we are with our own investment in AutoNation Express, and they are compatible in how they do business in that -- the AutoNation Express is the best price, that's the price on our site. It is the best price you can have. It can be the same somewhere else, but it can't be less and that it has to be about the brand AutoNation. So compared to where the fork on the road we were at 1.5 years ago, I couldn't be more pleased and delighted with where we are.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. And just last, if I could squeeze one more in, was, in light of Ford's recent towards commentary and I heard some remarks from you earlier on GM, can you just update us, Mike, on what you're hearing from the OEMs in terms of production and h
componenttext: That's great. And just last, if I could squeeze one more in, was, in light of Ford's recent towards commentary and I heard some remarks from you earlier on GM, can you just update us, Mike, on what you're hearing from the OEMs in terms of production and how you guys are thinking strategically moving ahead in terms of balance production versus demand?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if I go back to my keynote speech at the Automative World Congress in early January, I said this mark has plateaued at the auto industries in 3 phases and the most misunderstood and mismanaged phase is plateau, running at high 16 million, 17 million
componenttext: Yes, if I go back to my keynote speech at the Automative World Congress in early January, I said this mark has plateaued at the auto industries in 3 phases and the most misunderstood and mismanaged phase is plateau, running at high 16 million, 17 million units. This industry can, if run it rationally, you can still be quite successful and very profitable. So if I look at how the first half of the year is developed, well, from a market point of view, that's exactly where it is with retail in the second quarter, down, let's say, 2% at retail. But it's still considerably higher incentives for that to happen. The recent diversions in manufacturer behavior, I would give -- for instance, I would complement General Motors. And you certainly look at their results and you see if you find the right balance between supply and demand with a good disciplined approach and really marketing that's focused on the long-term, you can be quite successful. And the -- on the margin business, it's going to be very expensive from an incentive point of view. You don't take. On the other hand, we have other manufacturers who are still very aggressive in their plans and if you want to -- Bill already mentioned it, and if you want to look at Ford Motor Company where we have targets for the third quarter that significant number of our stores have targets that are 15%, 20%, 25% up to 40% higher than prior year, well, it's just not going to happen. It's totally unrealistic, and we're not going to chase it. And -- but it is disruptive in the marketplace and causes irrational behavior, and there's a price tag for that. And if you look at Ford's total incentives being up 28% in the second quarter, I don't think they got a return on that approach. So there's a good contrast as to what I was talking about and how it can be managed differently. Now we'll see what happens from this point. But the headline is progress is being made in principle, and maybe we'll make even more progress in the second half of the year.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Pat Archambault of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Pat Archambault of Goldman Sachs.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess, just building on that last point. I'm sure you saw the details of the Ford results, but one of the things that they did is announce a pretty meaningful production cut for the third quarter. And I was just wondering if your commentary is sort
componenttext: Yes, I guess, just building on that last point. I'm sure you saw the details of the Ford results, but one of the things that they did is announce a pretty meaningful production cut for the third quarter. And I was just wondering if your commentary is sort of reflective more of what was going on, up to kind of the end of the second quarter and if there's evidence that the tone has changed because certainly one would -- at least given some of their actions, one would expect that, that wouldn't have an impact.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Pat, that's a fair point. So the programs that are out there right now that I just referred to may be, you may have in the third quarter a transition quarter where they still have these very aggressive targets to try to clear inventory. But on the ot
componenttext: Yes, Pat, that's a fair point. So the programs that are out there right now that I just referred to may be, you may have in the third quarter a transition quarter where they still have these very aggressive targets to try to clear inventory. But on the other hand, they are cutting production so as to be in a better place in the fourth quarter. That could be. I still think where you take a significant percentage of your retail muscle and put it on the sidelines by putting out unrealistic targets is not the best way to get there. So your point is very fair. We could be a better place 3 months from now.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just on the stop sale inventory, I guess, you said that it would peak towards the end of the year, and I guess just so I better understand why that is. Because have they -- are they still in the process of identifying the numbers that you don'
componenttext: Got it. And just on the stop sale inventory, I guess, you said that it would peak towards the end of the year, and I guess just so I better understand why that is. Because have they -- are they still in the process of identifying the numbers that you don't have all of those, so that's why you're repairing some but your kind of identifying more inventory faster? Is that kind of the way it's working?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pat, that's very insightful. Again, exactly what's happening. So the good news first is that devices are beginning to arrive, and we're at a point with certain manufacturers where we can batch order devices and not go VIN by VIN. And we'll begin to repair
componenttext: Pat, that's very insightful. Again, exactly what's happening. So the good news first is that devices are beginning to arrive, and we're at a point with certain manufacturers where we can batch order devices and not go VIN by VIN. And we'll begin to repair those vehicles, we'll begin to sell those vehicles and we'll begin to recognize the compensation that is due on those vehicles from the manufacturer. So that's the good news. That would tend to say the worst is over. On the other hand, in the second quarter, they announced the -- another, I don't know, 10 million, 20 million of Takata airbag recall, which we don't have the VIN numbers yet, but those VIN numbers will come in the second half of the year and those parts will not come until the first half of next year because there -- on the passenger side, and they got to go through a whole design certification process to get the replacement parts to it. So it's a little difficult and a little risky to say we're out of the woods yet on Takata if I look at all the moving factors. So that's why we have good news, but I have the responsibility to tell you we still got a lot of VIN numbers that we are due that [indiscernible] are not parts.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: I'd like to follow up on M&A opportunities, the conversations given the retail market pulling back a bit of those are changing from maybe 6 months ago.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jon, could you take that for me, please?
componenttext: Jon, could you take that for me, please?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, Mike. Rick, we continue to see good opportunities out in the marketplace. I think the auto stock sector revaluation is working its way through. We have a number of conversations ongoing. That being said, given our position, we do get a look at
componenttext: Yes. Sure, Mike. Rick, we continue to see good opportunities out in the marketplace. I think the auto stock sector revaluation is working its way through. We have a number of conversations ongoing. That being said, given our position, we do get a look at a lot of opportunities and pass on the vast majority. We can be very selective in what we do, and you'll see us continuing to operate that way and looking for great brands, good cultural fit, excellent locations and markets where we have management infrastructure. So we're pleased with what we've done year-to-date. And I think over the next few years, there will be a lot of opportunities that we'll be able to take advantage of.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Also interested, your strategy to not chase some of these volume-based incentives. What about the risks there in terms of allocations and the implications for market share and maybe acquisition approvals?
componenttext: Also interested, your strategy to not chase some of these volume-based incentives. What about the risks there in terms of allocations and the implications for market share and maybe acquisition approvals?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Mike Jackson. Yes, I think it is a major source of irritation and friction between retailers and manufacturers. In one way, that was not -- it's not a difficult decision because the targets are so irrational or so unreasonable that you have no cho
componenttext: This is Mike Jackson. Yes, I think it is a major source of irritation and friction between retailers and manufacturers. In one way, that was not -- it's not a difficult decision because the targets are so irrational or so unreasonable that you have no choice, but to pull back volume and try to manage for growth. The preciousness and arbitrary -- and how arbitrary the targets are is the problem because you'll have neighboring stores of competitors that got a completely different target that's very reachable and therefore, they're on a different price basis. And then you have others who think they can just make it that when they're closing or not going to make it, they do extremely irrational things. So it really -- it's a difficult situation to manage. But you're right, it will be a source of friction. But the extreme practitioners of volume-based incentives are really, at this point, Nissan, Chrysler and Ford. I would say the intensity of the discussion between dealers, retailers and those companies is going up. Some are even questioning the legality of how those programs are run in the fairness of those programs. So it's the -- I think we're approaching a moment where I would hope that these extreme fair steps, which, again, I called out in my keynote speech in January, would be the issue in 2016 because you take away a growing marketplace and these stair steps really don't work because they're entirely based on growth. Hopefully, the industry over the second half of the year will come to a better place on understanding how these programs can work and can't work. But at the moment, it's a source of real friction.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think -- do you see some of your peers also backing away from chasing those incentives?
componenttext: And I think -- do you see some of your peers also backing away from chasing those incentives?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's just because of, where the calendar, I would observe everybody else has reported. And I see certain similarities. So all the publicly traded groups are behaving in a very rational way. They will all say, "hey, this market is plateaued. We need
componenttext: Well, it's just because of, where the calendar, I would observe everybody else has reported. And I see certain similarities. So all the publicly traded groups are behaving in a very rational way. They will all say, "hey, this market is plateaued. We need to bring -- we need to adjust costs and we need to bring inventories into life." I think it's very beneficial to the industry to see the big companies behave in a rational way. And then to call out why, if you look at Group 1, they did a fantastic job of saying, "You know what? These targets are irrational, not attainable. We're going to manage for gross because we can't get the volume numbers." And they actually increase their new vehicle front-end gross and gave up the volume. So finding that line is difficult and ongoing, but it is a point of contention. I don't, in principle, have a problem with volume targets because they're realistic and attainable. But when you put out -- when you've misjudged the market and you put out targets that are just not attainable and then you'd sprinkle it out there in a capricious arbitrary way, it really is disruptive in the marketplace and very difficult to manage, and you're going to have a lot of controversy with dealers. Yet, you can go out and find dealers who say they like it. Well, I can tell you something, they got a easy target. Yes, they get an easy target, you'll love it. And for all those -- and since we have such a big footprint in so many stores, we see that without line in reason, you end up with stores that get huge targets plus 25%. We have other stores that got lower targets than prior year. Go figure. So that's about as much color that I can give you.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Paresh Jain of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Paresh Jain of Morgan Stanley.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, you talked about the industry plateauing at a higher level now, but in a scenario where we saw declines, 10% to 15%, do you see yourself getting more aggressive at acquisitions or wait for signs of another upturn after such a decline?
componenttext: Mike, you talked about the industry plateauing at a higher level now, but in a scenario where we saw declines, 10% to 15%, do you see yourself getting more aggressive at acquisitions or wait for signs of another upturn after such a decline?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think a decline of 10% to 15% in auto sales would require a significant recession and a significant increase in interest rates above normal, so let's do interest rates first. They are so far from even being normal, let alone above normal. We're not g
componenttext: So I think a decline of 10% to 15% in auto sales would require a significant recession and a significant increase in interest rates above normal, so let's do interest rates first. They are so far from even being normal, let alone above normal. We're not going to have a decline in sales because there's been some dramatic significant increase in interest rates. I think we're looking at an environment where we have very low or reasonable interest rates and very low and reasonable gas prices, thereby, keeping the mix towards trucks for years. Now can something else happen in the world that hammers the U.S. with recession? I suppose that can happen, but I don't see that a significant recession that would decline sales by 10% to 15%. So my outlook is high industry sales, high $16 million, just over $17 million for the next several years.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. So then a broader question on the future of parts and services business here, which is more defensible, of course. Obviously, there's this rise of active safety and over-the-air update, which is a potential headwind for this business. But are
componenttext: Understood. So then a broader question on the future of parts and services business here, which is more defensible, of course. Obviously, there's this rise of active safety and over-the-air update, which is a potential headwind for this business. But are there any other offsets to it? Like are there new revenue streams dealers can capture especially related to fleet management?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the -- if you look at the safety devices that are coming around autonomy, and we are all for them, but if you really look at their realistic ability to become a significant percentage of the 250 million vehicles that are out there operating
componenttext: Well, I think the -- if you look at the safety devices that are coming around autonomy, and we are all for them, but if you really look at their realistic ability to become a significant percentage of the 250 million vehicles that are out there operating on the road and how long it takes to turn over, it's a very, very gradual process. At the same time, the cost of these systems and devices in vehicles is going up exponentially and the expertise to be able to deal with it is consolidating into fewer and fewer hands. So I think they offset each other for the next decade plus, and then ask me in 10 years for an update. I think we can really grow our customer care business open ended, including collision.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mr. John Murphy of Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mr. John Murphy of Bank of America.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, maybe just to stay on the parts and service for the first question, I mean, 2.2% on the same-store sales base was a little bit on the light side, but it sounds like your customer and warranty were up, I think, 6% and 9%, respectively, and the slight
componenttext: Mike, maybe just to stay on the parts and service for the first question, I mean, 2.2% on the same-store sales base was a little bit on the light side, but it sounds like your customer and warranty were up, I think, 6% and 9%, respectively, and the slight weakness came in collision, which is up only 1%. And the way you discussed it, it sounded like you're alluding to sort some of capacity constraints there, and you need to maybe add capacity for collision. So I'm just curious what the story is there and what you have in the plans to really increase capacity there.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now the good news, and Bill will give you the exact figures in a second, is that our customer pay business is up exactly where we wanted to be, solid mid-single digits. And what really has slowed is our internal business. Now here's the way to think about
componenttext: Now the good news, and Bill will give you the exact figures in a second, is that our customer pay business is up exactly where we wanted to be, solid mid-single digits. And what really has slowed is our internal business. Now here's the way to think about internal. That's volume related to our new and used business, so as we have this backlog of vehicles on hold, we are not repairing them until we get the parts from the manufacturer for the recall so that we can do the vehicle all at one time, make it frontline ready and then sell it. And upon sale, we'll recognize all that internal work that we did. So that has impacted our internal number. And Bill, why don't you talk about what internal was in the second quarter and talk about our hopes to add capacity on collision.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks, Mike. John, so like you said, we're up 6% in our CP, which is strong and steady performance, and we'll continue to see that kind of growth available in the future. Warranty was up 9%, but to Mike's point, we still have some pent-up demand th
componenttext: Okay, thanks, Mike. John, so like you said, we're up 6% in our CP, which is strong and steady performance, and we'll continue to see that kind of growth available in the future. Warranty was up 9%, but to Mike's point, we still have some pent-up demand there with cars that we have on hold that are waiting for warranty repairs from [indiscernible] and Takata air bags. On collision, you called that out right. We have record production levels, and we definitely have capacity issues. Not necessarily with people, it's more of a facility. And then on the internal piece quarter-over-quarter, year-over-year, we're down about 5%. But to Mike's point, that is 100% related to the number of new cars coming into inventory and the number of used cars that we're able to put through our system and put in the frontline. So as less cars on recall hold, we'll be able to see here an increase on our internal gross.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And John, we will add capacity on the collision side. We like that business, as I said. When an accident happens, there is a lot more work to do.
componenttext: And John, we will add capacity on the collision side. We like that business, as I said. When an accident happens, there is a lot more work to do.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: How fast can that capacity be added? Is that the kind of thing that's a couple of months, or is that 1 year or 2?
componenttext: How fast can that capacity be added? Is that the kind of thing that's a couple of months, or is that 1 year or 2?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it takes quite some time, but it's already underway. So Bill, when would you say the capacity comes online that will be able to be reflected in our numbers?
componenttext: Well, it takes quite some time, but it's already underway. So Bill, when would you say the capacity comes online that will be able to be reflected in our numbers?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll see a little bit of an increase in capacity in the third quarter, and then it will ramp up significantly in the fourth quarter through all of 2017.
componenttext: We'll see a little bit of an increase in capacity in the third quarter, and then it will ramp up significantly in the fourth quarter through all of 2017.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, that's incredibly helpful. And then just to also follow up on the stop sale. I mean, I understand there sounds like there's a little bit of a surge in parts and service on the warranty side and used vehicle sales that will kind of clear here. Just
componenttext: Great, that's incredibly helpful. And then just to also follow up on the stop sale. I mean, I understand there sounds like there's a little bit of a surge in parts and service on the warranty side and used vehicle sales that will kind of clear here. Just curious when you think that will happen. It sounds like it's probably first half of next year. And really in the interim, how much of a wait is that on results? I mean, is it really just the cost of carry of inventory that you won't get reimbursed for until you sell them? Or just really what's kind of the -- if you could quantify or even just give us some kind of magnitude of the wait that, that's creating on results.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The disruption, John, is significant. Literally, where do you put all these cars? And we've had to go out and rent storage lots and -- but still it's disruptive to frontline ready inventory to go. I think for the vehicles that we have right this moment, r
componenttext: The disruption, John, is significant. Literally, where do you put all these cars? And we've had to go out and rent storage lots and -- but still it's disruptive to frontline ready inventory to go. I think for the vehicles that we have right this moment, right this moment, I think the majority of the parts will come between now and year-end, and we'll be able to sell -- we'll be able to retail them, recognize the compensation we do -- or due and do the internal work and recognize that also. However, for these additional Takata air bags announced in the first half of 2016, there are no parts, and we will begin to get the VIN numbers very soon, which means, we're going to repeat this whole movie over, again, for this next wave, and that wave then takes us into 2017 before we get parts. Bill, anything you'd like to add there? Anything I missed?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Mike. I think you've said it perfectly. We'll be able to clear out of our existing inventory in Q3 and Q4. The real unknown is how extent the recalls in the future will be. There's more Takata air bags that will hit the recall over the coming months,
componenttext: No, Mike. I think you've said it perfectly. We'll be able to clear out of our existing inventory in Q3 and Q4. The real unknown is how extent the recalls in the future will be. There's more Takata air bags that will hit the recall over the coming months, but we have a plan and a process to deal with it, and we're executing upon it at a high level.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just lastly, Mike, you alluded to, and we've seen this data, where leasing has been surging as a percent of sales. And it looks like in the first half of the year, it was north of 30%, which is well above normal levels of 20%. Just curious
componenttext: Okay. And then just lastly, Mike, you alluded to, and we've seen this data, where leasing has been surging as a percent of sales. And it looks like in the first half of the year, it was north of 30%, which is well above normal levels of 20%. Just curious how that's impacting sales and profit here in the near term, and if you see that creating any disruption or how you might deal with it that we see this very large wave of vehicles coming back off lease in '18, '19 and '20.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's one of the distortions that I'm concerned about. So when I look at flat-out incentives, from the manufacturer, I really think they shouldn't break into double digit as a percent of their average MSRP. I think you hit a wall of diminish
componenttext: Yes, I think that's one of the distortions that I'm concerned about. So when I look at flat-out incentives, from the manufacturer, I really think they shouldn't break into double digit as a percent of their average MSRP. I think you hit a wall of diminishing return where the incentive is now at such a level that it's already depressing the resale value so you haven't really delivered the net -- reduced the net difference in the cost of the vehicle. Does that make sense? Where your next dollar of incentive doesn't have 10%, doesn't have the same impact when you went from 5% to 6%. There is a point of diminishing return that's dramatic. Second, I agree with you. Leasing is the same thing, it's -- you're selling the seeds of a day of reckoning that you really don't want, namely that you have so many vehicles coming back that are based on a residual value that's going to be higher than what the marketplace can handle. Now that -- all those risks are at the OEM level, not at the retail level, but we all know if you're basically pulling business forward now, that means that when the day of reckoning comes, the disruption is great. And I'd just rather see the business managed more rationally and with stability now so that this plateau period is more sustainable. That's what I'm advocating.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Absolutely, Mike. So we're seeing strong growth in Florida, especially in the Southern part the state. California is also improving and continuing to grow. Texas faces -- and Colorado energy market are facing extreme headwinds. Operationally, we've been able to sit here and adjust our business model and our cost structures to be able to combat that to the best of our ability. But as you see today, with oil in the $40 to $42 a barrel, it definitely poses some headwinds for the southern part of Texas.

componenttext: Okay, great. And then question on collision. As you expand that business, is that something that you could get involved in direct repair programs of the insurance companies and really drive outside volume to that business, sort of like the Caliber or Service Kings are doing? Or do you really sort of keep that as a more in-house boutique business?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we see it the way you describe it the first time. Again, it's part of our investment in the brand AutoNation why we did it, so we've extended the brand into our customer care products and protection products and have had amazing acceptance satisfactio
componenttext: No, we see it the way you describe it the first time. Again, it's part of our investment in the brand AutoNation why we did it, so we've extended the brand into our customer care products and protection products and have had amazing acceptance satisfaction and improved results for us for that move. And we intend to extend the AutoNation brand to the collision business. All our collision centers will be branded AutoNation, and the once we expand will be branded AutoNation. And so brand extension -- so one of the reasons we made a significant effort into the AutoNation brand and digital is for brand extension. So the heavy lifting [indiscernible] one in the sense that the risk and the investment that it took to establish the brand AutoNation is accomplished, the risk and the cost to build the digital muscle has been accomplished, and the obvious benefit for the existing business is there, that's fine. But the brand extension and the possibility that exists from having those 2 pillars are what we intend to realize over the next several years.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mr. James Albertine of Consumer Edge.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mr. James Albertine of Consumer Edge.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask -- and I know, Mike, you've alluded to this in your prepared remarks various times in the Q&A. But just sort of wanting to be very clear because it's a concern that's been voiced, I think, numerous times over the course of the last few mon
componenttext: I wanted to ask -- and I know, Mike, you've alluded to this in your prepared remarks various times in the Q&A. But just sort of wanting to be very clear because it's a concern that's been voiced, I think, numerous times over the course of the last few months, at least, to us among investor conversations. Do you believe that SAAR having grown to the point, which it was a record last year, has effectively pulled forward demand from the used vehicle market? And if not, where do you think or what indications are you seeing to give you confidence that when supply does ramp, there will be demand for those used vehicles?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think I've been very outspoken that -- and you're exactly on point that this is one of the reasons why I feel my stance at the beginning of the year was so important because ultimately, and I sort of alluded to it earlier, if the OEMs over do it and
componenttext: So I think I've been very outspoken that -- and you're exactly on point that this is one of the reasons why I feel my stance at the beginning of the year was so important because ultimately, and I sort of alluded to it earlier, if the OEMs over do it and push incentives too far and overproduce, push leasing too far, you are absolutely taking customers from the used vehicle market and converting them into the new vehicle market. And at the same time, you're  increasing the supply of used vehicle coming back to the market on a faster turn. Well, you can see that, that is unsustainable, and there will be a day of reckoning. So I've been very clear that there is a risk there. I don't think we've gone over the cliff yet. I think it's still -- there's still plenty of time to manage this rationally and disciplined. And don't forget the retail market for used vehicles is 40 million units. So if you put it all together, we're looking at a market that's 55 million to 60 million units between new and used. It's very manageable. But can you screw it up? Yes, you can. And that's why we're speaking up. And by the way, I have to say if I look at all of the other publicly traded groups that have reported, they have all talked about taking more a -- taking a disciplined approach on the cost side and on the inventory side. I haven't checked everybody's numbers, but I have the sense that everybody's day supply has come down sequentially during the second quarter. So everybody said they were doing and they're out there doing that, and that's a very strong single back to the manufacturers, which they don't like, but I think is healthy that we can have a very profitable, sustainable, rational plateau period until we have very high interest rates or a major recession, and then volumes will fall. Is that helpful?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's extremely helpful.
componenttext: It's extremely helpful.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Mr. David Lim of Wells Fargo.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're actually pushing back on orders, but that is a daily fight. Sometimes I feel like a Thanksgiving turkey, just being stuffed. It's a daily -- Bill, you want to -- you're  on the firing line, do you want to talk about it?
componenttext: We're actually pushing back on orders, but that is a daily fight. Sometimes I feel like a Thanksgiving turkey, just being stuffed. It's a daily -- Bill, you want to -- you're  on the firing line, do you want to talk about it?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's -- I think you said it right, Mike. It's a day-to-day fight. We've reduced our day supply by 6 days from the end of Q1 to the end of Q2. We'll be to our target area in the mid-60s by the end of Q3. But it is a store-by-store, model-by-model, bra
componenttext: Yes, it's -- I think you said it right, Mike. It's a day-to-day fight. We've reduced our day supply by 6 days from the end of Q1 to the end of Q2. We'll be to our target area in the mid-60s by the end of Q3. But it is a store-by-store, model-by-model, brand-by-brand fight. We're down 6,000 units sequentially. We're going to continue to get that down. But there's a tremendous amount of pressure coming from the OEMs to accept unneeded and unwanted inventory.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And by the way, just to make an observation, I ignore the day supply numbers in automotive news because they include fleet sales and the selling rate, which is ridiculous. It should be tell me what retail sales were versus retail inventory, that's the rea
componenttext: And by the way, just to make an observation, I ignore the day supply numbers in automotive news because they include fleet sales and the selling rate, which is ridiculous. It should be tell me what retail sales were versus retail inventory, that's the real world on what's going on with day supply. To pour in the -- to add in the fleet sales into the selling rate, to divide into retail inventory gives you an unrecognizable number as to what's happening in the real world in my humble opinion.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, absolutely. On the philosophical side, I mean, what is the rationale behind the irrational behavior by some of these OEMs? I mean, industry can't grow at 18 million, 19 million, 20 million maybe it could, but it doesn't seem that way. And you'
componenttext: Absolutely, absolutely. On the philosophical side, I mean, what is the rationale behind the irrational behavior by some of these OEMs? I mean, industry can't grow at 18 million, 19 million, 20 million maybe it could, but it doesn't seem that way. And you've cited several OEMs that are irrational. I mean, do you have any examples of OEMs that are more rational in this environment currently?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, sure. I mean, I already called out General Motors. Honda has always been very rational and disciplined, same with Toyota. By and large, the Germans has been -- they have a little diversions from their usual discipline with carrying far too much invent
componenttext: Oh, sure. I mean, I already called out General Motors. Honda has always been very rational and disciplined, same with Toyota. By and large, the Germans has been -- they have a little diversions from their usual discipline with carrying far too much inventory into 2016, which we're still trying to work our way through but that's sort of like an aberration, and I'm optimistic and hopeful that will come into line. And as far as what the issue is, there's agreement -- seems to be agreement on -- within the industry now on plateau. But then I get the speech for the next 20 minutes as to why their company is going to be different. And not everybody can walk on water. So that's an issue. And as far as the pressure, I can tell you as having been at the table, you still have relatively high fixed cost or some costs where the marginal cost to produce another unit, the pressure is absolutely there, and they recognize revenue on shipment to us, they stuffed us as a Thanksgiving turkey, they recognize their revenue, and there it is, that's the third real for the industry and why this is a struggle. But hey, we're speaking up, and I think we're making progress. We're not where we need to be, but I'm hopeful we're making progress.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Yes, Mike. Obviously, the opportunities come in, compensation, making sure we have our store staffed right, we have the proper headcount and the proper compensation plans to drive behavior. In addition to that, rightsizing our inventories, making sure our day supply is in line to lower our interest charge or floor plan, cost that goes along with that, and then day-to-day operational charges that come into it, whether it's service loaners or other SG&A items going store by store to rightsize those and make sure they're aligned to the volumes and to be able to service the customers the best way we can.

componenttext: My main question was about your acquisitions. You seem to be a lot more active than your competitors in the market on the public side. Wondering what allows you to continue to acquire versus some of your competitors. The commentary overall seems to be that the blue sky multiple is still high. Yet you seem to be finding deals. What's helping you, and what is the outlook?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, Irina. The last 3 or 4 years, we've been very active in our effort on the acquisition side. We think we bring a lot of advantages to the table, including being able to execute with the manufacturers to close transactions, which is very importan
componenttext: Yes, sure, Irina. The last 3 or 4 years, we've been very active in our effort on the acquisition side. We think we bring a lot of advantages to the table, including being able to execute with the manufacturers to close transactions, which is very important to sellers, how we take care of employees going forward with our world-class training and development programs that resonates with a lot of sellers and our ability, the real estate and facility side to navigate potentially complex facility parts of a transaction. So we think we bring a lot to the table, and we've been able to execute in the core markets that we've been in. So we're very pleased with that, and you'll see us continuing to work hard at it.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you comment a little bit in terms of what you are seeing in the market in terms of sequential trend and multiples availability of stores, seller expectations?
componenttext: Can you comment a little bit in terms of what you are seeing in the market in terms of sequential trend and multiples availability of stores, seller expectations?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say in terms of the multiples and the revaluation in the auto sector earlier this year that's working its way through, it's hard to generalize because there are so many different sellers and so many different circumstances. So every deal is differ
componenttext: I would say in terms of the multiples and the revaluation in the auto sector earlier this year that's working its way through, it's hard to generalize because there are so many different sellers and so many different circumstances. So every deal is different, but we're seeing less completely unrealistic sellers out there than we probably saw last year. So from that standpoint, it's getting a little easier and there's still a good flow of potential sellers that will be ready to divest their business over the next few years, and we're in dialogue with a lot of those folks.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: And the last follow-up on to that, in terms of preference, a share buybacks versus acquisitions, where does your preference lie?

componenttext: You want to take that, Mike?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's our classic answer that just look at our 15-year of track record, we look at where our stock is trading. And if it's attractive, we move aggressively. We usually have the balance sheet to do both, really, haven't had to make that trade-off. E
componenttext: Well, that's our classic answer that just look at our 15-year of track record, we look at where our stock is trading. And if it's attractive, we move aggressively. We usually have the balance sheet to do both, really, haven't had to make that trade-off. Existing business comes first on capital. We've always invested in our stores. We invested in our brand we've invested in our digital capability, That's first call, and then when we look at the balance between what we can buy the stock at and acquisitions. Certainly, the stock is extremely attractive in the first quarter, and we bought a lot.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Yes, and I would add here, Irina, if you take a look at the first 2 quarters of this year compared to last year, we spent between share purchase and acquisition over $550 million more this year than the prior year. So obviously, we're bullish on the things that we've been putting money into the first half of this year.

componenttextpreview: So I would say we are at a level of maturity where we are looking in the Northeast, and we've decided when we move into the Northeast, we'll move into Premium Luxury first. Strategically, despite the difficulties we already talked about with Premium Luxur
componenttext: So I would say we are at a level of maturity where we are looking in the Northeast, and we've decided when we move into the Northeast, we'll move into Premium Luxury first. Strategically, despite the difficulties we already talked about with Premium Luxury in this year strategically, we are very optimistic and confident about Premium Luxury, and it is the easiest way to extend our management into new markets without adding a lot of infrastructure, and we don't have brand launch costs or other costs. So it's a very cost-effective way to move into new markets.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, terrific. And then just one more -- just conceptually, Mike. I don't know if you're able get this sort of granularity on your purchasers on volume foreign and domestic. But as far as average age, have you seen any difference in buying habits fr
componenttext: All right, terrific. And then just one more -- just conceptually, Mike. I don't know if you're able get this sort of granularity on your purchasers on volume foreign and domestic. But as far as average age, have you seen any difference in buying habits from the 23, or call it the millennial generation as far as average age ticking up at all?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've been -- we've taken a close look at millennials for the last 5 years, it's been a tremendous -- we have a tremendous insight into it. All of our capabilities that we've talked about, a big part of that was the millennial generation and designing it
componenttext: We've been -- we've taken a close look at millennials for the last 5 years, it's been a tremendous -- we have a tremendous insight into it. All of our capabilities that we've talked about, a big part of that was the millennial generation and designing it in a way that will appeal to millennial generations, and we have more updates in the pipeline that will even make it more effective. My view is that millennials will buy cars. I think I have to check, but I think they could have bought more cars than any other generation. The millennials came of age with a great recession, they went back to school and double down on education and student debt. They're now entering the workforce, they have to pay down that student debt, but their fundamental desires to marry, have children, have a home, have a car are there. You have to do business with them differently, you have communicate with them differently, you have to know how to market to them differently, but those drivers are there. That's in principle of what we believe.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our last question comes from Mr. Mike Levin of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our last question comes from Mr. Mike Levin of Deutsche Bank.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just maybe one quick one where you've been talking about the divergence in behavior amongst OEMs. Mike, just wondering how you kind of see where the balance starts to tip one way or another. How many OEMs behaving like Ford, Fiat and Nissan? Does it take
componenttext: Just maybe one quick one where you've been talking about the divergence in behavior amongst OEMs. Mike, just wondering how you kind of see where the balance starts to tip one way or another. How many OEMs behaving like Ford, Fiat and Nissan? Does it take to kind of upset the apple cart and when do we sort become the frog in the slowly boiling water here?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say 3 is enough, so I think we're at a crucial point because if I look at the whole history, Chrysler was the first practitioner of aggressive stair steps. They were highly skilled, very professional and rational, and they probably today are
componenttext:
Yes, I would say 3 is enough, so I think we're at a crucial point because if I look at the whole history, Chrysler was the first practitioner of aggressive stair steps. They were highly skilled, very professional and rational, and they probably today are the most skilled practitioner of aggressive stair steps. Then you had Nissan arrived, which is just a loose cannon rolling back and forth across the deck, wreaking havoc. And now you've had Ford as of this year, join in. So if more go down that road, that is a real problem. But I think it's going to go the other way. The price tag of irrational stair steps incentives is beginning to be understood. And the damage to the brand, the change in your customer base, the impact on customer loyalty, the dissatisfaction and the fairness of pricing due to the fact that you've introduced a casino 3-car monte system, you've unleashed that on your customers. A manufacturer cannot talk about customer satisfaction in one breath and say, on the other hand, they're going to do aggressive stair steps because it's basically massively unfair to the customers. And finally, the relationship with your retailers that you really just wreak havoc. So I think the long term -- yes, in the near term, it's like heroine, it feels nice, it feels pretty good, but then you look in the mirror 1 day, and you look like Dory and Garettis [ph], and you realize you can't go on like this. So we're in a crucial point, could go either way. I'm saying it's, hopefully, going to go back more towards irrational. But 3 is enough. 
Great. Thank you, everyone, for joining us today. We very much appreciate your questions. We appreciate your time. All the best.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Thank you. This concludes today's conference. Thank you all for joining. You may now disconnect.
